nytimes_articles.headline: Suns' Main Stars Off and Stumbling
nytimes_articles.abstract: Charles Barkley, his jump shot oblique, frustrated even his grandmother tonight. Johnnie Mickens flew here all the way from Leeds, Ala., wished her grandson luck and then saw him dent the rim 16 times in the Phoenix Suns' loss to the Chicago Bulls in Game 1 of the championship series.   Interviewed late in the game by NBC, while a benched Barkley wore a towel on his head, Mickens said her grandson needs to rebound more fiercely and plant himself in the lane.

nytimes_articles.headline: Reviews/Music; Barber, Berlioz and a Cellist's Concerto
nytimes_articles.abstract: The New York Philharmonic, hurtling toward the end of its 150th-anniversary season, reached into its scrapbook of historical connections for its program last Thursday. Victor Herbert's Second Cello Concerto and Samuel Barber's Second Essay for Orchestra had their world premieres at Philharmonic concerts in 1894 and 1942, and the orchestra gave Berlioz's Symphonie Fantastique its first American performance in 1866, 36 years after its world premiere in Paris.    James DePreist conducted the orchestra with mixed but generally pleasing results. His account of the Barber, though on the brisk side, was a picture of lucidity. Details that are usually obscured -- fleeting brass effects, inner wind lines -- were spotlighted without being given an unnatural prominence. And the solo woodwind lines that weave through the essay, and also the Berlioz, were shapely and characterful and did double duty in elucidating the essay's charms and reminding listeners of one of the Philharmonic's strengths.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: It takes a measure of flexibility to cater a dinner for 1,200 people. BRIAN FINNERAN, the Waldorf-Astoria's assistant director of catering, thought everything was in order on Tuesday evening for the guests at a benefit for the One to One Partnership, an organization that provides mentors for disadvantaged youths around the country.    But then, he said yesterday: "CICELY TYSON arrived, and she had to have a baked potato. It is difficult to produce a baked potato on command, but we went back to the kitchen and rustled one up."

nytimes_articles.headline: NEWS SUMMARY
nytimes_articles.abstract: International A3-16  OIL EMBARGO PLANNED FOR HAITI  The United States and other United Nations Security Council members have decided to impose a mandatory worldwide ban on the supply of oil to Haiti as part of a new campaign to restore the deposed President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, to power.  A1  U.S. TO FREE HAITIANS AT BASE  The Clinton Administration announced that it would comply with a Federal court ruling ordering the release of 158 Haitian refugees, most of whom are infected with the virus that causes AIDS. They have been held at the American naval base in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba.  A12

nytimes_articles.headline: A Quest for Freedom Falls Short; Alien-Smuggling Suspect Eluded Immigration Net
nytimes_articles.abstract: Deported as an illegal alien and a felon, a man who the authorities say is a major smuggler of Chinese immigrants sneaked back into the United States, was arrested and then used a common ploy to stay in the country: He applied for political asylum.   The man, Guo Liang Chi, 27, is believed to have participated in the smuggling attempt that ended early Sunday, when a rusty freighter ran aground off the Queens shore with nearly 300 Chinese aboard. The authorities say Mr. Guo heads the Fuk Ching gang, which has forced payments from thousands of Chinese immigrants after they were brought illegally to the United States.

nytimes_articles.headline: Harter Is Interested in Cavs
nytimes_articles.abstract: Dick Harter, a Knicks assistant coach, said he would be interested in the Cleveland Cavaliers coaching job if contacted. Harter said he had not talked with the Cavaliers yet, but he has known Wayne Embry, the Cavaliers' general manager, for many years.    It has been reported that Cleveland is interested in speaking with Harter. Lenny Wilkens, the former Cleveland coach, resigned last month, then became the Atlanta Hawks' coach. Cotton Fitzsimmons, a longtime National Basketball Association. coach, and Paul Silas, the Nets' assistant coach, have also been mentioned as candidates in Cleveland.

nytimes_articles.headline: Don't Burn Hackney at the Stake
nytimes_articles.abstract: The National Endowment for the Humanities suffered during the Reagan and Bush years. Prominent academics accused it of putting ideology ahead of scholarship in awarding grants. The council that advises on what scholarship, research and public programs merit Federal money grew less distinguished, with fewer good scholars and too many nonentities appointed for ideological reasons.   Sheldon Hackney, whom President Clinton is considering for the N.E.H. chairmanship, could improve this sorry record. Mr. Hackney is a distinguished historian and a past provost of Princeton.  He has been a successful president of Tulane, and now heads the University of Pennsylvania. According to Brown University's president, Vartan Gregorian, Mr. Hackney has "a judicious, moderate temperament." That's what the Endowment needs.

nytimes_articles.headline: In Connecticut, Gun Ban Just Wouldn't Die
nytimes_articles.abstract: David S. Weaver, a lobbyist from Handgun Control Inc. who marched the halls of Connecticut's Capitol preaching the virtues of a ban on the sale of assault weapons, in the end likened the issue to "a bad cough that just wouldn't go away."   Others who watched the gun bill stagger from near-defeat to near-defeat, leading up to Tuesday night's hairbreadth victory in the Senate, said the medical analogy was apt. Connecticut's law, only the third in the nation after New Jersey and California, was seen today more as a symbol of tenacity than triumph. It wouldn't go away.

nytimes_articles.headline: Reviews/Music; A Pianist Offering Sound And Silence
nytimes_articles.abstract: Danilo Perez's set at Bradley's on Monday night started out slowly, with the rhythm section clunking along, not quite finding its momentum. The second tune, "Softly as in a Morning Sunrise," changed everything, and suddenly the set took off.   Mr. Perez, a young pianist, had paired himself with the young tenor saxophonist, David Sanchez, and together they managed to articulate about every note they played. Mr. Perez played be-bop lines double-handed, as if to put them in quotes, then abruptly shifted to wispy single-note right-hand ideas, changing the density of his sound. He threw in double-handed flurries, then used silence. And his rhythmic sensibility -- funny and always surprising -- kept his improvisations moving with the suspense of a good narrative. Everything was intense: Mr. Perez had the band moving with him, building wave after wave of pressure, following his improvisations until he finished his sermon.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Pop; A Subtler Sting Cuts Loose in a Smaller Hall
nytimes_articles.abstract: "It's cozy in here," Sting said as he looked around the airless Paramount on Tuesday night, and for a performer who has been on the arena circuit, it probably was. Sting was smart to return to mid-size theaters like the 5,605-seat Paramount for his current tour (although he's also opening some stadium shows for the Grateful Dead), because the music he's making now moves too fast and too subtly for most arena concerts. He writes and sings pop songs, but in concert they're laced with jazzy improvisation, transforming them between the lines of catchy choruses and rolling grooves. For all of Sting's associations with causes, and the earnest moping of many of his lyrics, he has rarely been a preachy performer in concert. And on Tuesday, Sting the musician was triumphant.   While Sting's bands, including the Police, have never been content to play songs by rote, his current group takes on all challenges, from odd meters and harmonic substitutions to the openness and understatement of a ballad. Sting's own bass was both foundation and fulcrum for a nimble four-piece band including Dominic Miller on guitar, David Sancious on keyboards and Vinnie Colaiuta on drums. They don't have the jazz pedigrees of his first post-Police group, but they mesh gleefully and they know which gambits belong where.

nytimes_articles.headline: Japan Is Represented by an Artist It Once Rejected
nytimes_articles.abstract: The last time Yayoi Kusama displayed her art at the Venice Biennale was 1966. Japan had refused to let her show in its official pavilion, and that was just the invitation the enfant terrible of the Japanese avant-garde needed. She crashed the prestigious event, covering the lawn with 1,500 mirrored orbs and frolicking among them in a red leotard, getting more attention than the official exhibit.   Twenty-seven years later Ms. Kusama, a small, slightly stooped rebel with dark eyes that are both soft and searing, is back. But there is a big difference this time. She has not only been invited to display her often disturbing, sexually charged works at this year's Biennale, but the exhibition will also be the first single-artist show ever mounted in the Japanese pavilion, a rare honor.

nytimes_articles.headline: Suffolk Lawmakers Pass Public Financing Bill for Campaigns
nytimes_articles.abstract: At the urging of supporters of Ross Perot, the Suffolk County legislature early today passed a bill calling for public financing of county election campaigns.   If the measure is signed by the County Executive and approved in a referendum this fall, Suffolk would become the first county in the state to have public financing of campaigns. New York City and 23 states have such laws.

nytimes_articles.headline: Afternoon of Thunder: Storms Came, Soaked and Roared On
nytimes_articles.abstract: Like an errant wave, a line of thunderstorms rolled over the New York metropolitan area late yesterday afternoon, felling trees and power lines, collapsing buildings and spawning funnel-shaped clouds.    In one New Jersey county, wind gusts of 92 miles per hour were recorded. In another, all four walls of a home-fixtures store under construction were flattened. And one storm-battered town, Bound Brook, N.J., declared a state of emergency. Across the region, at least a half-dozen people were injured, most seriously.

nytimes_articles.headline: After First Game Against Suns, It's Advantage, Bulls
nytimes_articles.abstract: It took the Chicago Bulls one game to take the homecourt advantage from the Phoenix Suns.   Playing with the poise and confidence that has allowed them to win back-to-back championships, the Bulls stunned the Suns by taking a 20-point second-quarter lead. The Suns rallied, but they never caught up. Meanwhile, their best player, Charles Barkley, was harassed into a 9-of-25 shooting night, bothered by the defense of Horace Grant and Chicago's taller front line.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: ANGIE DICKINSON, who is accustomed to playing glamorous roles in glamorous settings, is to make an appearance today at the New York Academy of Sciences on East 63d Street for a program titled "Closing In on Alzheimer's: a Progress Report From the Lab."   She will speak to physicians, scientists and representatives of Alzheimer's and geriatric-care organizations and the National Institute on Aging, who will also hear briefings by Dr. Dennis Selkoe, professor of neurology at Harvard Medical School, and Dr. Allan Roses, professor of neurology at the Duke University Medical Center. The program is sponsored by the Dana Alliance for Brain Initiatives, an organization established in New York in November to promote research.

nytimes_articles.headline: ANDREOTTI AT CRUX OF MURDER INQUIRY
nytimes_articles.abstract: Magistrates investigating corruption in Italy asked the Senate today to permit a formal inquiry into evidence that Giulio Andreotti, Italy's master politician, ordered the murder of a journalist in 1979.    The magistrates' evidence was set out in a 90-page dossier asking the Senate to suspend Mr. Andreotti's parliamentary immunity so he can be interrogated and tried. Mr. Andreotti is already facing charges of corruption and collusion with the Mafia.

nytimes_articles.headline: Court Won't Merge Districts But Orders Review by State
nytimes_articles.abstract: The New Jersey Supreme Court yesterday declined to order three Bergen County school districts to merge to help achieve racial balance, but it upheld a lower-court ruling that requires the state to study the issue.   The high court's decision was significant for what it did as well as what it did not do: it chose not to rule on whether a court may order regionalization as a judicial remedy for de facto segregation. The justices also said it was unnecessary for them to decide at this point whether the State Board of Education has the authority to require regionalization.

nytimes_articles.headline: If It's Sunday, It Must Be Azinger
nytimes_articles.abstract: Paul Azinger still isn't completely over the emotions of the miracle bunker shot that won him the Memorial Tournament last Sunday, but on the eve of the first round of the Buick Classic, he could at least say that he no longer feels bad for Payne Stewart.   A few hours after Azinger had holed the 25-foot sand shot at the 72d green and gone from a stroke behind Stewart to a stroke ahead in a matter of seconds, he was still feeling melancholy about administering such a bitter defeat to his best friend on the PGA Tour. Then he opened his locker.

nytimes_articles.headline: Democracy's Doldrums
nytimes_articles.abstract: A book entitled "Giants of the Democratic World" would be exceedingly short, briefer even than "Gems of English Cookery." Nobody can recall when so many leaders have found so little public favor. Not only are incumbents of various brands unpopular. They are also generally smaller than life. Europe as a whole fits the writer Jane Kramer's description of Austria: a grand opera performed by understudies.    Bill Clinton, whose 36 percent approval rating is the lowest for any President after four months, can take cold comfort from the advice of a fellow sufferer. During a White House visit, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada urged the President to "wear unpopularity as a badge of honor." But proud defiance did not save Mr. Mulroney, who in February stepped down as party leader as his Progressive Conservatives plunged to a 21 percent approval rating, chiefly due to economic miseries.

nytimes_articles.headline: Tirana Journal; 'Hallelujah' Is Heard in the Arch-Atheist's Temple
nytimes_articles.abstract: If Enver Hoxha, Albania's dictator for more than 40 years, is turning in his monumental grave on a hillside above this capital, it would not be surprising.   On the steps of the spectacular marble-and-glass structure resembling a winged pyramid that was built to honor the man who made Albania the only country that outlawed religion, men and women who said they came from the Foursquare Gospel Church of Los Angeles were laying hands on shattered limbs, blind eyes and aching bodies the other day, and with many a "Praise the Lord!" and "Hallelujah!" prayed for healing.

nytimes_articles.headline: Uncle Sam Still Wants You to Live a Lie
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Some murky descriptions of a "compromise" on lifting the military's ban on homosexuals have appeared in the news. President Clinton has referred to a plan in which, "if you don't ask and you don't say and you're not forced to confront it, people should be able to serve." The particulars of a "don't ask, don't tell," proposal, supported in its various forms by Sam Nunn, Les Aspin and Barney Frank, remain vague. What this lack of clarity likely reflects is that such plans are not fully formed. Yet the emerging compromise may also remain poorly articulated because something in its essence defies logic.

nytimes_articles.headline: Will Mr. Marino Help the Park?
nytimes_articles.abstract: Every year, it seems, Ralph Marino gets the opportunity to be a hero to millions of New York State residents who care about the environment. And every year the majority leader of the Republican-controlled Senate takes a pass. Now, in the waning days of the present legislative session, he has still another chance.   At issue is Gov. Mario Cuomo's proposal to create a permanent trust fund for land preservation, watershed protection, waste treatment and recycling. The Assembly has already approved similar legislation sponsored by Speaker Saul Weprin. If Mr. Marino tells his Senate colleagues to go along, the trust fund is certain to become law.

nytimes_articles.headline: Don't Close Drop-In Centers for the Homeless
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   The proposed closing of homeless drop-in centers in New York City because of budget cuts is anger-provoking and saddening.

nytimes_articles.headline: NEGOTIATORS TRY TO REOPEN TALKS
nytimes_articles.abstract: The United Nations peace mediator, Lord Owen, embarked here today on another round of talks to repair a Balkan peace effort that he says has gone badly off track, threatening among other things to draw Croatia more directly into the fray.   Amid setbacks to Bosnian Croats at the hands of Muslim forces in Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as growing tension over parts of southeastern Croatia under the control of Serbian irregulars, Lord Owen and Thorvald Stoltenberg of Norway began the first of three days of meetings that will culminate in talks Saturday in Geneva between President Alija Izetbegovic of Bosnia, a Muslim, and Mate Boban, leader of the Bosnian Croats.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.N. COUNCIL PLANS TO ORDER FULL BAN ON OIL FOR HAITI
nytimes_articles.abstract: The United States and other United Nations Security Council members have decided to impose a mandatory worldwide ban on the supply of oil to Haiti as part of a new campaign to restore to power the deposed President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide.   Plans for enforcing the blockade, which also applies to arms supplies, have not been worked out yet, diplomats said today. But the resolution imposing the ban, which is expected to be approved formally next week, will be adopted under Article 7 of the United Nations Charter, which allows the Council to enforce its orders.

nytimes_articles.headline: Refugees Blocked From Getting Legal Help
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Immigration and Naturalization Service, which has pledged to send a tough signal to Asian smugglers and would-be immigrants by fighting the entry of the nearly 300 Chinese refugees who washed up on a Queens beach on Sunday, is blocking legal help to them, immigrant advocate groups and lawyers say.   At the immigration service detention center at 201 Varick Street yesterday, a sign on a bulletin board near the holding cells said that until further notice, no lawyers would be permitted to visit the refugees. When a reporter asked to take a closer look, a guard, who would not identify himself, snatched the sign down.

nytimes_articles.headline: METS INSIDE PITCH
nytimes_articles.abstract: JOSE GUZMAN worked seven and two-thirds innings last night, striking out seven in gaining the triumph for the Cubs. . . . General Manager AL HARAZIN denied persistent reports of a potential trade sending BOBBY BONILLA to the Giants for first baseman WILL CLARK.  "It defies sense from every end," said Harazin, who pointed out that Clark has a no-trade clause in his contract. . . . Manager DALLAS GREEN has sent second baseman JEFF KENT to the bench for the next three games and ordered a crash course in selectivity a the plate and instincts in the field. Green made the move with three straight games against tough right-handers -- Guzman, TOMMY GREENE and CURT SCHILLING.  "He's a tough kid, and we all like that," Green said of Kent. "We all respect that. But it has to be channeled." CHICO WALKER started at second last night and homered in the fifth inning. . . . MIKE MADDUX, who yielded a two-run home run to RICK WILKINS in the seventh, has now given up nine runs in his last four and two-thirds innings of relief. . . . Bonilla's 10-game hitting streak ended.

nytimes_articles.headline: RECALL IS ORDERED FOR WORM PROBES
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Federal Government has announced the recall of an electronic device used by fishermen to shock worms to bring them to the surface of the ground for use as bait, saying similar devices had caused the deaths of more than 30 people since 1973.   The Consumer Product Safety Commission formally ordered the recall on June 1 of about 83,000 of the devices, which run an electric current through the ground and send out vibrations that shock worms.

nytimes_articles.headline: McIlvaine Leaves Padres; Thoughts Turn to Mets
nytimes_articles.abstract: Joe McIlvaine resigned as general manager of the San Diego Padres yesterday, then said he was going to do something he hasn't done since 1974: take some time off.   But, McIlvaine said last night, a team might be able to convince him to cut short a planned four-month hiatus made possible by a Padres contract that will run through October. Which leads to the question of whether McIlvaine, one of the chief engineers of the winning Mets teams of the 1980's, could find his way back to his former club.

nytimes_articles.headline: Home Video
nytimes_articles.abstract: With summer movies flooding theaters, studio video divisions are thinking months ahead. Will the big titles -- a "Last Action Hero," say -- be finished with their theater runs in time to be in stores by Christmas? Equally important, which of this summer's releases has the right stuff to carry a low price tag on tape?   Movies priced low to sell (usually about $25) are vital even to video dealers whose business is primarily based on rentals.

nytimes_articles.headline: Cutting Social Charges : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding "Economies Are Facing 'Alarming' Jobless Rise" (June 2) byCarl Gewirtz: .It is time for some of us in the business world who have been silent too long to speak up: The real reason for our problems has to do with governments that pre

nytimes_articles.headline: Farrow Spurns Allen's Plea For a Truce
nytimes_articles.abstract: Fresh from her victory over Woody Allen in the fight for custody of their three children, Mia Farrow turned down an attempt by Mr. Allen to call a truce yesterday. Instead, she went to court again, seeking to make his defeat still more emphatic.   The estranged pair and their corps of lawyers, trailed by the usual phalanx of reporters, went to Surrogate's Court in Manhattan to begin arguing Ms. Farrow's lawsuit to nullify Mr. Allen's adoption of two of their children. If Judge Renee H. Roth overturns the adoptions, it would deny Mr. Allen any right to see Moses, 15, or Dylan, 7, leaving him only with limited contact with Satchel, 5, his biological child with Ms. Farrow.

nytimes_articles.headline: Boeskys Agree On Settlement For a Divorce
nytimes_articles.abstract: Ivan F. Boesky has reached a divorce settlement with his former wife, Seema, under which he will receive a lump payment of $20 million, a house valued at $2.5 million and more than $2 million a year for life, courthouse officials said yesterday. The amount was about half of what Mr. Boesky was seeking.   The settlement was approved by Justice Phyllis B. Gangel-Jacob in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. It was sealed, as is required by law in any divorce case. Mrs. Boesky's lawyer, Sara Gold, declined to comment on the settlement and Mr. Boesky's lawyer, Renee Schwartz, could not be reached for comment.

nytimes_articles.headline: Woman, 60, Charged With Killing Daughter Over Crack Use
nytimes_articles.abstract: A 60-year-old Bronx woman shot and killed her adult daughter after begging her to abandon her crack habit, the police said yesterday.   The mother, Jean Lee, of 1055 University Avenue in High Bridge, was arrested Tuesday on murder charges after she shot her daughter, Avis Swan, 42, once in the lower right abdomen, said Sgt. John McCluskey, a police spokesman. The daughter died instantly in the mother's apartment in a building overrun by drug use and drug dealers.

nytimes_articles.headline: Koresh, on Tape, Screams About Children
nytimes_articles.abstract: As a furious gun battle raged at the Branch Davidian cult's compound in Texas, the group's leader, David Koresh, telephoned the Waco police, screaming, "You killed some of my children."    "There is a bunch of us dead and a bunch of you guys dead now -- that's your fault," Mr. Koresh yelled as Federal agents from the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms stormed the Branch Davidian compound outside Waco.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Rock; The Deliberately Derivative, From Jellyfish
nytimes_articles.abstract: Rock can be the noise of primal passions, but it doesn't have to be simple. From the Beatles and the Beach Boys down through Queen, Squeeze and XTC, rock has also been a medium for ingenuity and duplicity. Ever-so-clever pop constructions, full of key and tempo and textural changes, can carry equally clever lyrics that defy the simple pleasures of their sugar-coated tunes. Rock's most lapidary songwriters are willing to trade a show of spontaneity for a show of precision and whimsy, demonstrating just how elaborate a song can be.   Jellyfish, a band from San Francisco that performed on Friday night at the Academy, proudly joins pop's lineage of tuneful tricksters. Its songs cheerfully invite listeners to spot the derivations: the bouncy chords from Squeeze, the falsetto voice over rumbling drums from the Beach Boys, the vocal-harmony glissandos from Queen, the arrangements from the Beatles's "Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band." Its verbal strategies are close to those of Squeeze; songs from Jellyfish's two albums, "Bellybutton" and "Spilt Milk" (both on Charisma , used big words and fragmented narratives to address topics like the resemblance of rock fan clubs to televangelists' fund-raising ("Joining a Fan Club"), getting away with betrayal ("All Is Forgiven"), a philandering principal ("Now She Knows She's Wrong," which rhymes "D.N.A." and "P.T.A.") or masturbation ("He's My Best Friend").

nytimes_articles.headline: Stanley Cup Returns to the Citadel in Montreal
nytimes_articles.abstract: Aside from a colorful coach and a first-rate goalie, the Montreal Canadiens are sort of nondescript. They lack flashy personalities and superstars found even on lesser teams. They have no single celebrity close to the stature of Wayne Gretzky of the Los Angeles Kings, who was last seen tonight shaking the hands of the Canadiens on the Forum ice.   Gretzky and his teammates performed that ceremonial chore because the gritty, balanced Canadiens possess that one, bright, shining object that every team in the National Hockey League seeks when it arrives at training camp in the late-summer heat of September. They have the Stanley Cup, which they hoisted high after defeating the Kings by 4-1.

nytimes_articles.headline: Essay; The Polish Thatcher
nytimes_articles.abstract: Next to Hillary Clinton, the most powerful woman in politics today is Hanna Suchocka. This is true despite the fact that the Government headed by the first female Prime Minister of Poland -- and the first woman to lead the nation since Queen Jadwiga in the 14th century -- was recently overturned by a single vote.    Her former Minister of Justice, whom she fired the week before for his habitual tardiness, claims he did not oversleep. He says he left a wake-up call with the hotel operator, who rang him; he told his wife to call him from home, which she did; and he set his alarm, which duly rang. Despite this tintinnabulation of bells, he just did not make it to the Parliament in time for the confidence vote, and the Government fell. We all have mornings like that.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Talk With Bhutto: Is Her Sure Touch Slipping?
nytimes_articles.abstract: Benazir Bhutto sat in a stuffed armchair in her office in Islamabad, her eyes flaring at times in anger, her voice harsh with frustration and irritation.   Once beloved by Pakistani voters, once a darling of Washington, once Prime Minister, she has seen her political fortunes evaporate like a puddle on a scorching pavement.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Race for Drumthwacket
nytimes_articles.abstract: Christine Todd Whitman nearly unseated Senator Bill Bradley two years ago by attacking New Jersey's Governor, Jim Florio, on taxes. Having won the Republican gubernatorial primary this week with more attacks on Mr. Florio, she has proved her strength at campaigning. She now has five months to prove her worth for office, in a contest where the heat is already rising.   Following the Republican victory over a Democratic incumbent in the Texas Senate race last week, the race for Drumthwacket -- the governor's residence in Princeton -- shapes up as the next significant measurement of Democratic strength. New Jersey's will be the only major statewide vote in November where an incumbent seeks re-election. By chance, he's a Democrat whose public approval ratings are down near President Clinton's.

nytimes_articles.headline: Third Wave: 1776, 1950 and 1993
nytimes_articles.abstract: It happens every 43 years, like scoreboard clockwork: The United States national soccer team knocks off England and sends segments of the British Empire into convulsions of sporting despair.   Right on schedule today, in a U.S. Cup match, the Americans pulled off a convincing 2-0 upset over England before 37,652 fans at Foxboro Stadium. Energized by the addition of foreign-based players Tab Ramos, Tom Dooley and Eric Wynalda, the United States went airborne twice to shock an English side that already was consumed by self-analysis.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. to Release 158 Haitian Detainees
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Clinton Administration said today that it would comply with a Federal court ruling and release 158 Haitian political refugees, most of them infected with the virus that causes AIDS, who have been held at the American naval base in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba.   The decision means the detainees will be admitted into the United States in the next few days, with most of them expected to head to south Florida.

nytimes_articles.headline: Campbell to Get Old Job Back
nytimes_articles.abstract: Mike Keenan, the Rangers' new coach, said today that Colin Campbell should be back with the team next season as an assistant coach, a role Campbell lost last January when Roger Neilson was fired as head coach.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Experts Say 'Safe Havens' Won't Help Much
nytimes_articles.abstract: American intelligence officials have told the White House that the plan to create "safe havens" for the besieged Muslims in Bosnia would do little in the long run beyond creating six impoverished refugee compounds with limited law and order and no economic future, a senior Clinton Administration intelligence analyst said today.   And the official said there is little hope of restoring a single Bosnian state along the lines of the plan developed by Lord Owen and Cyrus R. Vance. He added that the most likely outcome is the partition of the country into Muslim, Serbian and Croatian areas.

nytimes_articles.headline: How Christian Coalition Endorsed Candidates
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   In "Christian Coalition Only Guided Voters" (letter, May 28), Ralph E. Reed Jr., executive director of that organization, states on the subject of endorsements of school board candidates, "Neither the Christian Coalition nor any of the 2,000 churches that received our voter guides endorsed any candidate or slate of candidates."

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Is Sending Planes to Bolster U.N. in Somalia
nytimes_articles.abstract: The United States has sent four heavily armed gunships to Somalia to be available for any retaliation by United Nations forces against a faction that has been blamed for the deaths of 23 peacekeepers, Administration officials said today.   Three of the AC-130H "Specter" gunships have already landed in neighboring Djibouti, giving United Nations forces new offensive power to strike at arms caches controlled by the faction headed by Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid.

nytimes_articles.headline: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding "Lots of Fuzzy Feminist Thought in Silly Books" (Opinion, April 28) by Katherine Knorr: .As one who innocently wandered into a "prestigious" graduate program some years ago, naively inspired by my love of the culture and l

nytimes_articles.headline: INSIDE
nytimes_articles.abstract: More Cuts at the Pentagon   The Defense Secretary has told the services to prepare for further spending reductions totaling billions of dollars in next year's budget. Page A22. Wet, Gusty and Damaging    Thunderstorms rolled over the New York metropolitan area, felling trees and power lines and spawning funnel-shaped clouds. Page B9. Trying to Control Custodians    The New York City Board of Education has turned to the State Legislature in its efforts to win greater control over school custodians. Page B1. Bulls Beat Suns in Opener    The Chicago Bulls beat the Phoenix Suns, 100-92, in the opening game of the National Basketball Association championship series. Page B13.

nytimes_articles.headline: 1893:Hidden Raphael? : IN OUR PAGES: 100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: LONDON - A replica or copy of Raphael's "Belle Jardinière" which is to be sold today [June 10] at Christie's has a curious history. At one time the gem of the late Bishop of Winchester's collection, it was bought from the Gallery of Baronne

nytimes_articles.headline: Whitman and Florio Attack As New Jersey Battle Begins
nytimes_articles.abstract: The morning after winning the Republican gubernatorial primary, Christine Todd Whitman began her general election race today by breaking bread with her Republican rivals at a "unity brunch" and revamping her campaign staff, putting her brother in charge.    And she went after the man whose job she wants, Gov. Jim Florio, accusing him of playing politics by flirting with tax cuts in an election year.

nytimes_articles.headline: Plan to Protect 40,000 Acres of Pine Barrens
nytimes_articles.abstract: After years of conflict over the fate of the Long Island Pine Barrens, a bipartisan group of state legislators proposed a plan today to preserve 40,000 acres of the endangered watershed and wildlife habitat on the Island's East End.   But though it creates a mechanism for keeping the region wild, the legislation leaves unresolved the critical issue of how to pay for 8,000 acres of privately owned land in the heart of the proposed reserve.

nytimes_articles.headline: Ukraine Has Reason to Distrust Russians
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Let us hope "Lighten Up on Ukraine" by Bruce G. Blair (Op-Ed, June 1) will encourage some State Department policy makers to be more sensitive to the concerns of Ukraine and other non-Russian countries about Russia.

nytimes_articles.headline: Fighting Defamation Isn't Like Spying
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   From 1968 to 1975, I was director of European affairs for the Anti-Defamation League. It was with keen interest that I read the two May 28 Op-Ed articles headlined "The A.D.L. Under Fire," particularly intrigued that the critical article by Dennis King and Chip Berlet appeared in the positive form of a Star of David, while Abraham Foxman's official view appeared in its negative image.

nytimes_articles.headline: Moves by President To Invigorate Staff Supported by Perot
nytimes_articles.abstract: In a distinct warming trend in a chilly relationship, Ross Perot today cited President Clinton's recent staff shakeup as a sign that Mr. Clinton "is starting to get it together."   Mr. Perot, in particular, had kind words for David R. Gergen, the former adviser to Republican Presidents who was hired by Mr. Clinton last month. "With his background and experience, he can make a big contribution," Mr. Perot said in a conference-call interview with several reporters, which was reported by The Associated Press.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: CASSANDRA DANSON has filed for divorce from the "Cheers" star TED DANSON, citing irreconcilable differences as the cause for the end of their 15-year marriage.    The petition was filed last Thursday in Superior Court in Santa Monica, Calif., The Associated Press reported yesterday. Mr. Danson, who is 45, and his wife, 55, have been separated since October.

nytimes_articles.headline: Critic's Notebook; Getting to Know Mrs. Clinton in Both Her Hats
nytimes_articles.abstract: So thoroughly identified is Hillary Rodham Clinton with the Administration's health-care plan that her appearance tonight on NBC, her first acceptance of such a network invitation since she became First Lady, signals a new stage in a lowering political battle as well as in the image-refurbishing of a still undefined First Lady.   As bits of the health plan have been exposed, Mrs. Clinton, cloistered with her health-care acolytes, has been seen by most Americans only as a flash on the evening news. A few weeks ago, however, she permitted several magazines and newspapers a peek behind her veil in preparation for the unveiling of the big plan, a process that is beginning to seem like an overlong strip tease, with the climactic take-it-off moment still months away.

nytimes_articles.headline: DNA From the Age of Dinosaurs Is Found
nytimes_articles.abstract: A team of scientists says it has recovered and identified the oldest DNA ever found: genetic material from an extinct weevil that lived during the age of dinosaurs.   The achievement apparently refutes the long-held view of many biologists that DNA of so great an age, some 80 million years older than the oldest previously known DNA, would have decayed completely, leaving no trace.

nytimes_articles.headline: Human Rights for Women
nytimes_articles.abstract: What to do about Bosnia? Development? At its world conference on human rights in Vienna, which begins today, the United Nations will wrestle with these issues. Women's human rights are at the center of both of them.   Women's human rights? Yes. In New York, U.N. diplomats from a world outraged about the Balkan carnage, including the systematic rape of countless women, have argued about what to do. And elsewhere in the U.N., diplomats are looking a year ahead toward a world conference on population and development, where women hold the key.

nytimes_articles.headline: Washington Talk; What's Delaying Choice Of High Court Nominee
nytimes_articles.abstract: When Justice William J. Brennan Jr. announced his retirement from the Supreme Court, President George Bush took three days to name David H. Souter to fill his seat. One year later, he took four days to say he wanted Clarence Thomas to replace Thurgood Marshall.   By contrast, President Clinton's search for a Supreme Court Justice has taken almost three months -- far longer than any President in more than 25 years. Day after day, week after week, the President or his aides have said they were on the verge of an announcement, only to pull back. White House officials today assured reporters again that the nomination was imminent -- certain to come by Saturday.

nytimes_articles.headline: Cyclist Shoots 2 in Harlem
nytimes_articles.abstract: A gunman on a bicycle wounded two pedestrians during a ride-by shooting in Harlem last night, the police said. Maria Herzo, 33, was shot in the stomach, and a 2-year-old girl was hit in the right hand. Both were described as being in stable condition at St. Luke's Hospital. Sgt. Anthony Barlanti, a police spokesman, said the incident took place about 8:40 P.M. in front of 453 West 125th Street. Witnesses said the assailant pulled a handgun, fired at the two and then pedaled into the night before bystanders could stop him, Sergeant Barlanti said. The motive was not known.

nytimes_articles.headline: Uncle Sam Still Wants You to Live a Lie; Don't Give Up
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   As a lesbian convinced of the importance of living a life of integrity, I strongly disagree with the "don't ask, don't tell," philosophy on the ban of gays and lesbians in the military.

nytimes_articles.headline: Only Thing Roy Can't Stop Is Praise for His Goaltending
nytimes_articles.abstract: The image did not flash on the scoreboard until after the game, until after the Montreal Canadiens had won their 24th Stanley Cup. The little cartoon man trudged into a phone booth, puffed up his chest, and -- poof! -- the big Superman crest exploded onto the screen that hangs over the center of the Forum ice.    SuperPatrick screamed the words across the top of the picture, a tribute to the man chiefly responsible for the celebration that took place in Montreal tonight.

nytimes_articles.headline: RESULTS PLUS
nytimes_articles.abstract: TENNIS  Qualifier Upsets Navratilova on Grass  Kristine Radford of Australia, a 23-year-old qualifier ranked 170th in the world, shocked top-seeded Martina Navratilova, 2-6, 6-4, 6-3, in a third-round match yesterday at the Edgbaston grass-court tournament in Birmingham, England. Navratilova looked to be on her way to a comfortable victory when she won seven straight games to take the first set and lead by 2-0 in the second. But Radford leveled the set at 3-3, then won the set four games later on a Navratilova double fault. Radford broke serve to lead by 5-3 in the third set and won on her second match point when Navratilova netted a forehand return of serve. (AP) Sampras Is Defeated: Pete Sampras played as if he preferred to be somewhere else rather than at London's Queens Club yesterday. Now he has the time to go there. The world's top-ranked player suffered a 5-7, 7-5, 6-4 loss to Grant Stafford of South Africa in the second round. Stafford is ranked 110th in the world. "There are times when you miss home a little bit," said Sampras, who has been away from Tampa, Fla., for five weeks. "And this is one of those times." But Sampras said he would stay in London to prepare for Wimbledon, which starts on June 21. (AP)

nytimes_articles.headline: Greene Is a Big Hit As Phils' Top Pitcher
nytimes_articles.abstract: Everyone knows about the avalanche known as the Philadelphia Phillie offense that's hit the National League this season. Too many teams have spent too much time digging out from under Philadelphia's league-leading 311 runs, 119 doubles and 58 home runs to have not noticed the bruising meted out wherever the Phillies go.   What has been greeted with a lot less notoriety, but has proved to be the undoing of just as many opponents, is the Phillies pitching. It has been just as sharp, just as decisive, and just as commanding as anything coming off the Phillies' bats. And no one epitomizes that sudden burst of confidence and success more than Tommy Greene.

nytimes_articles.headline: Missing Man in Bombing Case Is Said to Be in Iraq
nytimes_articles.abstract: A missing figure in the World Trade Center bombing case -- a man said to have helped teach Mohammed A. Salameh to drive a van -- is in Iraq and has turned down an F.B.I. request to return, Federal investigators and a spokesman for Arab causes said yesterday.   Court papers call the missing man a "confidential informant" who told Federal agents that he had accompanied Mr. Salameh, the first suspect arrested, to a Jersey City apartment where traces of explosive damage were later found, and had helped Mr. Salameh, two days before the Feb. 26 blast, to learn to drive the kind of Ryder van that prosecutors say carried the bomb.

nytimes_articles.headline: Ousted British Official Assails Prime Minister
nytimes_articles.abstract: Just when it seemed that John Major's fortunes could hardly sink any lower, the Prime Minister was subjected today to a withering attack in Parliament from former Chancellor of the Exchequer Norman Lamont.   Two weeks ago Mr. Major dismissed Mr. Lamont from the Government's second most powerful post. Today, in a 20-minute speech slipped in as a surprise, the new back-bencher got his revenge.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Wants to Keep Menus Honest on Nutrition Claims
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Food and Drug Administration is expected to announce new rules on Thursday to require all restaurants to back up any nutrition claims on their menus.    The proposal would undo a compromise the agency reached with the White House in the waning days of the Bush Administration in order to persuade Mr. Bush to sign the Nutrition Labeling and Education Act, which requires virtually every packaged food to be labeled with its nutritional content.

nytimes_articles.headline: Budget Talks With Mayor In a Standoff
nytimes_articles.abstract: Four days after the City Charter deadline for adopting a new budget, talks between the City Council and the Dinkins administration degenerated yesterday into a schoolyard standoff. The two sides spent the day finger-pointing and saber-rattling, but failed to make progress on the three main issues dividing them.   The Council Speaker said the standoff was the Mayor's fault for leaving City Hall the other night when, in the Speaker's view, a deal was at hand. But the Mayor's staff said the Council had derailed the deal by insisting on last-minute concessions that the Mayor could not accept.

nytimes_articles.headline: HOPES ARE DASHED ON AIDS THERAPY
nytimes_articles.abstract: An air of enthusiasm rose over the ninth international AIDS meeting here before Dr. Jonas Salk's team reported today on his experimental immunotherapy for people infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS.   But the enthusiasm, largely drummed up by a public relations blitz from the company that makes the immunotherapy, quickly disappeared as the report drew a cool reception from experts at the meeting.

nytimes_articles.headline: What They're Reading
nytimes_articles.abstract: Judith Rosenbauer, director of the English Theater in Frankfurt, is reading Dostoevski's "The Gambler," about a man's experiences in a German casino. ."I started reading it because I was recently in the casino in Baden-Baden, which is Eur

nytimes_articles.headline: Turks in Berlin Call 1-Hour Strike To Urge Action on Arson Attacks
nytimes_articles.abstract: As attacks against foreigners continue, Turkish leaders in Berlin have announced plans for a one-hour strike on Friday.   "This action is an appeal from Turkish business people to politicians, urging them to take truly effective measures against terror and racism," said Kenan Kolat, one of the organizers. "Politics treats the attacks on foreigners as a series of isolated acts, but it is a problem of the entire society."

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: An article in Business Day on June 2, about plans by Telemundo Group Inc. to develop a Spanish-language news service for cable television in the United States and Latin America, misstated the number of Western news agencies with bureaus in Cuba. Along with Reuters, several news agencies, including Agence France-Presse and Agencia EFE of Spain, have bureaus in Cuba.

nytimes_articles.headline: Lawyer Says Ex-Officer Ready to Admit Charges
nytimes_articles.abstract: Michael Dowd, the police officer whose arrest last year led to a widespread investigation of corruption in the New York City Police Department, has agreed to plead guilty to charges that he bought and sold cocaine and that he regularly received cash payments from drug gangs, his lawyer said last night.   The agreement, coming after nearly a year of three-sided negotiations involving Federal and state prosecutors and Mr. Dowd's lawyer, Marvin Hirsch, means that the former officer will avoid a prison term that could have stretched well beyond the year 2015. Instead, he will face a sentence of between 12 1/3 to 15 2/3 years.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: An article yesterday about a judge's decision to order the immediate release of Haitian refugees held at a detention camp in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, misstated the age of the camp in some copies. It was set up in November 1991. The article also misstated the affiliation of a lawyer, Michael Ratner. He is with the Center for Constitutional Rights.

nytimes_articles.headline: School Board Presses Fight With a Union
nytimes_articles.abstract: The New York City Board of Education, stalled in its efforts to win greater control over school custodians in contract talks with their union, has turned to the State Legislature to get what it wants.   Legislation that the Democratic-led Assembly passed by a slim margin today would provide principals a stronger role in evaluating and promoting custodians, a group whose singular independence has given them a "quasi-license to steal," school investigators say.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Whistle-Blowing Nuclear Worker Gains
nytimes_articles.abstract: An administrative law judge for the United States Labor Department found today that managers at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory had retaliated against a technician there by creating a hostile work environment after he raised concerns about radiation exposure on the job.   The finding by the judge, Theodor von Brand, upheld a decision issued last year by the Labor Department's district director in Nashville and appealed by the technician's employer, Martin Marietta Energy Systems, which manages the Oak Ridge center for the Energy Department.

nytimes_articles.headline: No Headline
nytimes_articles.abstract: "The possibility of cloning dinosaurs is very remote. Probably impossible. But we have now at least shown that DNA from the age of dinosaurs actually has survived." -- Dr. RAUL J. CANO, of California Polytechnic State University.  [ A1:4. ]

nytimes_articles.headline: Sports of The Times; Stanley Cup 'Back Home;' Wayne Gone?
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE most famous sports trophy in North America came out of hiding last night, but the most famous hockey player in the world sent clear signals that he was preparing to fade away from the ice.   Even while they were dancing in the Forum and outside on Rue Ste. Catherine to celebrate the Canadiens' 24th Stanley Cup, Wayne Gretzky himself revealed that he might have played his last minute of hockey in the Kings' 4-1 loss.

nytimes_articles.headline: Los Angeles Elects a Conservative As Mayor and Turns to a New Era
nytimes_articles.abstract: Los Angeles entered a new political era today as its conservative Mayor-elect, Richard Riordan, outlined plans to use his skills as an entrepreneur to bring the city out of its economic slump and social turmoil.   The first Republican to lead the city in a generation, Mr. Riordan, a self-made millionaire of 63, campaigned with promises to lure more businesses and hire more police officers, sweeping aside the coalition of blacks and white liberals that had sustained the retiring Mayor, Tom Bradley, for 20 years.

nytimes_articles.headline: Yanks and Abbott Dig an Early Hole
nytimes_articles.abstract: There was no ninth-inning rally for the Yankees tonight, no warm feeling as they fled Royals Stadium and traveled to Milwaukee and no reason to be proud of their effort. There was only another early deficit, another suspect start from Jim Abbott and another night when the Yankees did not show any road flair.   For the fourth time in six games on this trip, the Yankees fell behind by at least three runs after three innings and were unable to recover for the third time as the Royals surged to a 10-3 victory.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bolivian Assured of Presidency as Foe Concedes
nytimes_articles.abstract: Gonzalo Sanchez de Lozada was guaranteed the presidency of Bolivia today when his chief rival, a former dictator, conceded defeat in Sunday's elections.   A Sanchez de Lozada presidency is certain to step up Bolivia's free-market policies, which include low inflation and privatization, efforts that he initiated in 1985 as Planning Minister.

nytimes_articles.headline: Out of the Blue, Space Telescope Sees 'Naked' Stars
nytimes_articles.abstract: Astronomers examining pictures from the Hubble Space Telescope have caught sight of stars in a stunning state of undress, stripped of their dense cloak of gases and exposed to their cores.   "These objects represent a totally new population of very blue stars," said Dr. Guido De Marchi, a Hubble astronomer who announced the discovery here today at a meeting of the American Astronomical Society.

nytimes_articles.headline: Pop and Jazz in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Yanni  Gershwin Theater 222 West 51st Street Manhattan Through Sunday    When Yanni, the popular composer of New Age symphonic music, describes his esthetic philosophy, he likes to use space-age metaphors. Late in Tuesday's opening-night show, he told the story of an astronaut on the space shuttle who gazed down at the earth and noticed that the familiar borders separating European countries on maps were invisible. The lesson of the story, he declared, is that the divisions between people -- and by implication between musical genres -- are only "something in the mind."

nytimes_articles.headline: 1918:Cannon Fodder : IN OUR PAGES: 100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: FRENCH FRONT - It is now known that during the recent fighting the Germans committed a new crime in forcing French prisoners, with rifles and revolvers leveled at them, to drag mine-throwers to the fighting line. This outrage is proved by a letter found o

nytimes_articles.headline: Dean and Duchesnay Will Divorce
nytimes_articles.abstract: The ice-dance stars CHRISTOPHER DEAN and ISABELLE DUCHESNAY, married for less than two years, are seeking a divorce, Duchesnay said yesterday in Paris.   Dean and JAYNE TORVILL won the Olympic title for Britain in 1984 and four world championships.

nytimes_articles.headline: METRO DIGEST
nytimes_articles.abstract: NEW JERSEY CAMPAIGN BEGINS   A day after winning the Republican gubernatorial primary, Christine Todd Whitman began her general election race by breaking bread with her Republican rivals at a "unity brunch" and revamping her campaign staff, putting her brother in charge. A1. NEW YORK CITY  SMUGGLING SUSPECT RETURNED TO U.S.   Despite deportation as an illegal alien who had committed a felony, the man authorities say is a major smuggler of Chinese immigrants re-entered the United States illegally and was arrested and convicted of illegal entry. Yet, he was allowed to remain in the country in a legal limbo as an applicant for political asylum. A1.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mondale (Tokyo) Is Excited, Holbrooke (Bonn) Surprised
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Clinton Administration may have left some heavyweight candidates for top ambassadorial jobs hanging for a long time, but when it made up its mind, it acted quickly.   The phone calls began shortly after dawn on Tuesday, in an account given by someone involved in the process. Secretary of State Warren Christopher, on his way to Andrews Air Force Base to begin a European tour, rang up Richard C. Holbrooke with a surprising offer of an ambassadorship.

nytimes_articles.headline: CLINTON NOW SEEMS PREPARED TO DROP ANY WIDE FUEL TAX
nytimes_articles.abstract: Barely a day after giving up his demand for a $71.5 billion tax on the heat content of energy sources, President Clinton seemed close today to retreating from his fallback position as well: that any substitute for that tax must cover the gamut of fuels, from oil to electricity to natural gas.   Instead, Senate and Administration officials said, Mr. Clinton's aides were looking closely at a proposal by Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat Louisiana, to replace the heat tax with a $40 billion tax on gasoline and other transportation fuels and $30 billion in Medicare cuts through the fiscal year 1998.

nytimes_articles.headline: Aspin Tells Pentagon to Find Billions More in Budget Trims
nytimes_articles.abstract: Defense Secretary Les Aspin, opposed to further cuts in military programs on the ground that readiness would be endangered, has nonetheless quietly told the armed services to prepare for as much as $20 billion more in reductions for the next fiscal year to meet Congressional requirements.    The Pentagon's problem stems from a confluence of factors: budget accounting practices, the cost of new programs, budget limitations imposed by Congress and the different priorities of Mr. Aspin and Congress. That adds up to a situation in which the Pentagon, after already making steep cuts beyond those that had been planned by the Bush Administration, would still exceed its $263 billion budget for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bridge
nytimes_articles.abstract: Many players from the New York metropolitan area posted high North American scores in the Epson Worldwide Bridge contest last week. Among them were: Friday East-West: Robin Kay and Aaron Silverstein, 10th with 68 at Culbertson, Manhattan. Saturday North-South: Ronnie Kutic and Berl Sternberg, 5th with 71 percent at the Bridge Deck, Scarsdale, N.Y.; Joan Pollenz and Lisa Yellis, 7th with 69 percent at the Vanderbilt, Lake Success L.I.; Mel Colchamiro and Janet Schiff, 8th with 69 percent at Grand, Massapequa L.I. Saturday East-West: J.J. Adamo and Sandy Burns, 5th with 69 percent at West Hill, Englewood, N.J., and Jane Heilbron and Joan Mendell, 7th with 68 percent at the Bridge Deck, Hartsdale, N.Y.   Michael Rosenberg and Zia Mahmood, playing at Honors Club in Manhattan, had 68 percent Friday night, the top North-South score in New York City. On the diagramed deal they outwitted the official analysts. They pushed to six no-trump, with a natural sequence that included a strongly invitational raise from three no-trump to five no-trump.

nytimes_articles.headline: Hawks Sign Blaylock to 5-Year Deal
nytimes_articles.abstract: MOOKIE BLAYLOCK is set to direct the Atlanta Hawks' offense for five more years.   The Hawks announced yesterday that Blaylock has agreed to a five-year contract, terms of which were not disclosed. The new deal negates the option year he had under his old contract with the Nets.

nytimes_articles.headline: Rudolph to Work on Behalf of Berlin's Bid
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Olympic gold-medal winner, WILMA RUDOLPH, will be working to help Germany land the 2000 Olympic Games for Berlin.   "Their chief competition is Beijing, China, and Sydney, Australia, but I think Germany would be better suited, from the significance of world peace," Rudolph said in Nashville.

nytimes_articles.headline: Croats in Bosnia Walk Out Of Talks With Government
nytimes_articles.abstract: The commander of the Bosnian Croats' militia abruptly walked out of United Nations cease-fire talks today, dashing hopes for a halt to a territorial free-for-all that has left hundreds dead in central Bosnia.   But fighting around Travnik was said to be waning after five days of skirmishes that emptied the town of Croats. A day after taking command in a shake-up of the Bosnian Army, the former head of strategic planning, Rasim Delic, had ordered a unilateral cease-fire in the area, the Army said.

nytimes_articles.headline: Cubs Show Why Mets Eye Deal for Pitcher
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Mets want to deal, and if they are able to deal big, they want to trade for quality starting pitching.   For instance, they recently tried to package shortstop Tony Fernandez and a right-handed reliever -- either Anthony Young or Jeff Innis -- to a National League club for a front-line starting pitcher, according to a baseball executive with knowledge of the club's recent talks. The club was believed to be the Phillies, and the pitcher the Mets wanted would have been Tommy Greene, Curt Schilling, Terry Mulholland or Ben Rivera.

nytimes_articles.headline: Twins' Movie-Making Vision: Fighting Violence With Violence
nytimes_articles.abstract: Few films begin and end with such unsparing brutality as "Menace II Society."    "We wanted to show the realities of violence, we wanted to make a movie with a strong antiviolent theme and not like one of those Hollywood movies where hundreds of people die and everybody laughs and cheers," said Albert Hughes, the 21-year-old who directed this movie with his twin brother, Allen.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Rule of Seven : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding "Let's Put the Group to Work" (Opinion, May 15): .I cannot imagine anything worse than transforming the Group of Seven into an international steering committee, as Richard Burt in effect suggests. Such arrogance would further margin

nytimes_articles.headline: Books of The Times; The Art of Going Gentle Into That Good Night
nytimes_articles.abstract: Days of Grace  A Memoir  By Arthur Ashe and Arnold Rampersad.  Illustrated. 317 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $24.    In the penultimate chapter of "Days of Grace: A Memoir," Arthur Ashe describes a time he spent in the hospital, which turned out to be shortly before his death from AIDS-related pneumonia on Feb. 6, 1993.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Dance; Valmont and the Sly Marquise Are Back to Their Old Tricks
nytimes_articles.abstract: What is it about the libertine excess of 18th-century France that so fascinates the creative artists of our time? Part of the answer may be found in "Les Liaisons Dangereuses," a clever and unsettling ballet that American Ballet Theater performed for the first time on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.   As expected, the choreographer, Christian Holder, has come up with his own treatment of "Les Liaisons Dangereuses," a now celebrated novel that Pierre-Ambroise-Francois Choderlos de Laclos published in France in 1782. What is more surprising is the experimental manner -- rooted more in mime than in a dance pulse -- with which Mr. Holder approaches this tale of corrupt aristocrats playing games by their own rules of sexual license.

nytimes_articles.headline: Officer Charged With Unlicensed Driving
nytimes_articles.abstract: A 28-year-old New York City police officer was arrested yesterday in Staten Island and charged with driving without a license, the police said. He was suspended from the force after he was arrested.   The officer, John Norton, who has been assigned to the 120th Precinct in St. George, Staten Island, for seven months, was arrested at 2 P.M. after he drove to the department's Health Services building, said a police spokesman, Sgt. John McCluskey. The officer's license had been suspended for allowing his auto insurance to lapse and abandoning a car, Sergeant McCluskey said.

nytimes_articles.headline: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding "Lots of Fuzzy Feminist Thought in Silly Books" (Opinion, April 28) by Katherine Knorr: .Ms. Knorr dismisses feminist thought as a soft science in search of someone to blame. But for each woman on this planet who has an education, a

nytimes_articles.headline: Art Work Is (Yes, Really) Garbage
nytimes_articles.abstract: Mierle Laderman Ukeles is staring at a 200-foot-long mound of decomposing leaves.   "This is sculpture already," she says.   Michelangelo had his ceiling. Frank Lloyd Wright had his falling water. Ms. Ukeles has her garbage.

nytimes_articles.headline: Jordan, N.B.A.'s Garbo, Speaks
nytimes_articles.abstract: It was just a routine night for Michael Jordan. He scored. He won. He talked.   Before the Bulls beat the Suns, 100-92, in Game 1 of the National Basketball Association finals tonight, Jordan broke his silence with reporters by chatting with his friend, NBC's Ahmad Rashad, for an interview that was shown at halftime. After he led the Bulls with 31 points, Jordan marched into the interview room and, sensing that his team was in control as it goes for its third straight title, announced, "It's all about making history now."

nytimes_articles.headline: Gala to Feature Dances of Protest
nytimes_articles.abstract: The New Dance Group was founded in 1932 to bring the uplifting force of dance into the lives of the workers of New York City. One of a number of visionary dance projects of the time, it alone survived and flourished, offering inexpensive classes and rehearsal space and producing dance by choreographers whose names read like a roster of American modern dance.   Many of those choreographers will be represented in a gala retrospective tomorrow night at 7:30 at the theater at La Guardia High School, on Amsterdam Avenue at 64th Street, just west of Lincoln Center. The program will feature signature pieces created between 1936 and 1981 by 17 men and women, which will be performed whole or in part.

nytimes_articles.headline: Civilian Pilots Allowed to Use Satellite Navigational System
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Federal Aviation Administration today authorized civilian pilots here and abroad to use a satellite-based navigation system that will enable them to choose direct routes without relying on navigational aids on the ground.    The system's electronic signals will also enable the airlines and private aircraft to land at 2,500 airports lacking the electronic beacons that the biggest airports use to guide airplanes in landing.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Theater; A First Lady's Fantasy Of Travel Back in Time
nytimes_articles.abstract: In "Where's Mamie?," the latest of Michael John LaChiusa's cycle of mini-musicals about First Ladies of the United States, a forlorn Mamie Eisenhower is alone in the White House, toasting herself on her birthday in 1957. Her solitude is suddenly interrupted by news of the civil rights conflict in Little Rock, Ark., and soon she is off on a trip to the past, to wartime North Africa in an attempt to enlist her husband in support of black students.   This very fanciful 30-minute musical journey, a highlight of the Ensemble Studio Theater's Marathon of short plays, also involves Dwight D. Eisenhower and Kay Summersby, his driver during the war, and reaches far out for Marian Anderson as Mamie's traveling companion. As Mr. LaChiusa has demonstrated on numerous occasions, he has a fervid imagination and the will to break new musical ground. A previous First Lady musical, "Over Texas," focused on the contrasting roles of the personal secretaries to President and Mrs. Kennedy.

nytimes_articles.headline: America, the Nonsexist
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Your report of Wellesley's commencement exercises (May 29, some editions) tells us Wellesley students, when singing "America the Beautiful," crown America's good with "sisterhood," as opposed to the "brotherhood" Katherine Lee Bates wrote. Readers might be interested to know how Macalester College, a co-educational school addresses the issue:   America! America!

nytimes_articles.headline: Pop and Jazz in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Suede  Irving Plaza    On the great carousel of pop poses, gay male androgyny has come around again with the emergence of Suede, the latest English pop sensation to venture an American tour. This time, the self-consciousness runs thicker; Suede's music borrows liberally from elders like the Smiths, Queen, the New York Dolls and especially the early-1970's Ziggy Stardust incarnation of David Bowie. But as it did in the 1970's glam-rock that Suede revives, androgyny means both a refusal of convention and an ultimate liberation: the chance to become pure desire, free even from sexual differences.

nytimes_articles.headline: Allen Follows Montana to the Chiefs
nytimes_articles.abstract: First JOE MONTANA.  NowMARCUS ALLEN.  If Kansas City's backfield isn't the best in the National Football League, it's the most honored.   Allen, No. 12 on the N.F.L. career rushing list, signed three one-year contracts with Kansas City yesterday and acknowledged that one major lure of the Chiefs was playing with Montana. The three-time Super Bowl most valuable player left San Francisco for Kansas City six weeks ago.

nytimes_articles.headline: Popular Mayor of Atlanta Will Not Seek Fourth Term
nytimes_articles.abstract: In what he called a "gut-wrenching but regrettably necessary decision," Mayor Maynard Jackson said today that he would not seek election this year to a fourth term.   The announcement means that for the first time in two decades Atlanta's politics will be open to new faces and names that may not be tied to the city's pivotal role in civil rights history.

nytimes_articles.headline: Yonkers Defends Actions in Housing Desegregation Case
nytimes_articles.abstract: The City of Yonkers tried to show in Federal District Court yesterday that it has had a change of heart and is moving aggressively to create subsidized housing for more than 700 poor or middle-income families in largely white neighborhoods. At the same time, though, it blamed a court-appointed official for the city's failure so far to move a single family into any apartment.   The trial, before Judge Leonard B. Sand in lower Manhattan, opened yet another phase in a desegregation case that has dragged on for 13 years.

nytimes_articles.headline: For a Clear and Credible Line on Tokyo
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Clinton administration has been struggling for months to devise a coherent policy toward Japan. Due to a slow appointment process and a dearth of experts on Japan in the administration, what we have instead is confusion. .This confusion has been th

nytimes_articles.headline: Easing Out the F.B.I. Chief
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Administration wants the F.B.I. Director, William S. Sessions, to step down and is negotiating when and how, officials said. Page A18.

nytimes_articles.headline: First Lady Tries to Placate Doctors
nytimes_articles.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton offered an olive branch to doctors today by suggesting that they were not mainly to blame for high health-care costs.   Speaking at the celebration of the 100th anniversary of the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, Mrs. Clinton backed away from her recent sharp attack on what she called price gouging in the medical system. Today she said the national health crisis had been caused by a combination of factors, including the lack of individual responsibility for preventive care.

nytimes_articles.headline: Why Not Draft Lawyers for Public Service?
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Dr. Richard C. Reynolds has a great idea in "Make Health Reform Work. Draft Doctors" (Op-Ed, June 1). Why not take those professionals who have to take nasty courses in college like organic chemistry, who spend four years and more than $100,000 in medical school, who give up years of their youth in specialized training and 80-hour-a-week internships, and punish them even more? Surely, doctors won't mind forfeiting a year or two of income while their friends and acquaintances in other professions continue to buy homes, save money for their children's education and secure their future.

nytimes_articles.headline: Russia Seeks Leeway
nytimes_articles.abstract: Contending that an agreement on conventional forces in Europe is not letting it respond to new threats to its border security on the south, Russia has told the Clinton Administration that it wants to revise the treaty. Officials said Washington was not interested in reopening the issue.    Article, page A5.

nytimes_articles.headline: China's Population Concerns the World
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   As Chinese scientists committed to research and training in population and health in the world's most populated country, we are seriously concerned by pressure to withdraw international assistance to China's family planning and research programs.   China has made an unprecedented effort in the last two decades to control rapid population growth in a country that has to feed 22 percent of the world's population on 7 percent of the world's arable land under relatively poor economic and environmental conditions. The Chinese family planning program has faced great difficulties and challenges, and the Chinese people, especially Chinese peasants, have made great personal sacrifice for the collective interest of the country, which is considered as the greatest virtue in our culture.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Architecture; Jewish Museum Renovation: A Celebration of Gothic Style
nytimes_articles.abstract: WHAT did Kevin Roche set out to do? How well did he do it? Was it worth doing? If Mr. Roche's design for the Jewish Museum's new expansion brings to mind Goethe's standard formula for critical appraisal, that may be because the design itself is somewhat formulaic. It is an appealing formula, and Mr. Roche carries it off with devotion and skill. The building does not lack conviction. But it does lack depth.   This Sunday's long-awaited reopening of the museum after two and a half years of renovations brings to fulfillment an ambitious plan, conceived in 1989, to give the Jewish Museum a home worthy of its mission. With a permanent collection of more than 27,000 objects -- ranging from archeological artifacts to contemporary paintings -- this is the major American museum devoted to Jewish culture and history. The museum has grown in stages since its founding in 1904, when it was provisionally housed in the library of the Jewish Theological Seminary. Since 1947, it has occupied the former Warburg Mansion on Fifth Avenue at 92d Street. The choice of Mr. Roche, an internationally celebrated architect whose achievements include the master plan for additions to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, insured that the museum would assume an even grander presence on Museum Mile.

nytimes_articles.headline: Restaurant Critic Is Named
nytimes_articles.abstract: The appointment of Ruth Reichl as restaurant critic of The New York Times was announced yesterday by Warren Hoge, assistant managing editor for cultural news and style coverage.   Ms. Reichl has been the restaurant critic for The Los Angeles Times since 1984 and its food editor, in addition, since 1990. She succeeds Bryan Miller, 41, who has requested a reporting assignment with the paper's style staff after nine years as critic.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Art; Jewish Museum as Sum of Its Past
nytimes_articles.abstract: Although there are kinks to be worked out, and several galleries that are only partly installed, the Jewish Museum, which will reopen its doors on Sunday, clearly intends to live up to its name as never before. For the first time in its 89-year history, it has stretching room: its newly refurbished and seamlessly expanded home, the Gothic-style former Warburg mansion on upper Fifth Avenue, now houses twice as much gallery space as it did before.    There's some unevenness among the three inaugural exhibitions: "From the Inside Out: Eight Contemporary Artists," an overly tame group show of contemporary art; "Collecting for the 21st Century: Recent Acquisitions and Promised Gifts," a wide-ranging display of recent acquisitions, and "Culture and Continuity: The Jewish Journey," an epic presentation of objects from the museum's permanent collection, whose final sections will not be completely installed until later this summer. But together these shows affirm that the museum is expanding and deepening its focus on Jewish culture and history in ways that promise to have immense value for Jews and non-Jews alike.

nytimes_articles.headline: McGwire Flunks Heel Checkup
nytimes_articles.abstract: As if last place wasn't bad enough, the Oakland Athletics have been dealt another blow. Slugger MARK McGWIRE may be out for at least another three weeks with a heel injury.   McGwire, who went on the disabled list May 14, had a cast removed from his left foot Wednesday, but his bruised heel showed little improvement.   "There's still soreness when he puts pressure on it, still that knife-like feeling when he pushes off," trainer BARRY WEINBERG said.

nytimes_articles.headline: It's Not Too Late for Clinton to Get It Right; On to New Hampshire
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   It is startling to watch with what glee the Republicans are trekking to New Hampshire, convinced that their efforts to tar Bill Clinton as a "tax and spend liberal" will bring dividends in 1996. The ink wasn't dry on the election results before Jack Kemp hit the mashed-potato circuit.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: Being on stage hardly makes ITZHAK PERLMAN nervous, but he was a touch apprehensive about his debut as a theatrical actor. "I have made little sort of appearances on television shows, but I have never acted live on stage before," he said yesterday, talking about his co-starring role in a children's play to be performed twice today at Lincoln Center as part of a series called "Celebrations."   The play, "Claire's Broom Detective Agency: The Mystery of the Missing Violin," tells the story of a renowned violinist, Abraham Strauss-Stokowsky (played by Mr. Perlman, who else?). "In the middle of a rehearsal, my fiddle disappears and Detective Claire is in charge of finding it," he said.

nytimes_articles.headline: Senate Panel Making Painful Progress on Budget
nytimes_articles.abstract: Slowly and painfully, the elements of a Senate compromise on President Clinton's package of tax increases and spending cuts began to fall into place today. They include a comparatively small tax on motor fuels, a partial rollback of Mr. Clinton's plan to raise Social Security taxes and a patchwork of spending cuts in Medicare, food stamps and other benefit programs.   But while the outlines of an agreement among the Senate Finance Committee's 11 fractious Democrats were clear, details remained muddy, and officials said no final accord had been worked out.

nytimes_articles.headline: METRO DIGEST
nytimes_articles.abstract: FLORIO BANS BLIND TRUSTS   Governor Florio has issued an executive order to eliminate the use of blind trusts by key state employees and prohibit companies owned by these workers from doing business with government. . The rationale is in part political, as Mr. Florio tries to distance himself from an inquiry into a company owned a former aide. A1. NEW YORK CITY  PEACE CORPS JOB FOR BELLAMY?   President Clinton is expected to nominate Carol Bellamy, former president of New York's City Council, as director of the Peace Corps, Administration officials say. Ms. Bellamy is an investment banker for Bear Stearns. A16.

nytimes_articles.headline: As Iran Chief Faces Vote Today, West's Doubts Rise
nytimes_articles.abstract: When President Hashemi Rafsanjani first took office in 1989, some diplomats greeted him as a moderating force in a country dominated by radical Islamic clerics.   Just over a year ago, some Western envoys hailed the ouster of some parliamentary hard-liners as a victory for the President and a turning point in Iran's relations with the West. But as Mr. Rafsanjani heads into an election on Friday that he seems virtually assured of winning, diplomats are increasingly skeptical that he will use his second four-year term to cut off Iran's support for shadowy groups threatening other governments in the region.

nytimes_articles.headline: Studies Reveal Suggestibility Of Very Young as Witnesses
nytimes_articles.abstract: The testimony of small children has usually been considered truthful unless proved otherwise.
