Over the past decade such testimony has led to convictions in many child-abuse cases, and the younger the child, the less likely psychologists have thought it was that information could have been fabricated. But now a series of recent studies has turned this conventional wisdom on its head.    Researchers have found new evidence that persistent questioning can lead young children to describe elaborate accounts of events that never occurred, even when at first they denied them.

nytimes_articles.headline: Medical Group Battles to Be Heard Over Others on Health-Care Change
nytimes_articles.abstract: When the 435 delegates to the American Medical Association's governing congress arrive here Sunday for their annual summer meeting, the first speaker on the agenda will be Hillary Rodham Clinton. The doctors will be listening closely for hints on who among them -- if anyone -- the Clinton Administration has been heeding as it develops its proposal for overhauling the nation's health-care system.   Until recently, there would not have been any question. The medical association was the undisputed, all-powerful voice of medicine in Washington, and no major overhaul had much chance of succeeding without its cooperation.

nytimes_articles.headline: The New Guard: Bulls' Armstrong Makes His Point
nytimes_articles.abstract: B. J. Armstrong no longer has to prove he belongs in the Chicago Bulls' starting lineup. He has convinced his teammates, his coach, and his opponents.   The latest example was Game 1 of the National Basketball Association finals. Most people expected the Suns' Kevin Johnson to outplay Armstrong. In fact, point guard was a position where the Suns' expected to have a decided advantage.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Says It Will Send 300 Troops To Balkan Republic to Limit Strife
nytimes_articles.abstract: The United States announced today that it would send 300 peacekeeping troops to Macedonia in about a week to help contain the Bosnian war. The gesture responds to Europe's desire for more American involvement in the region and exposes American soldiers to minimal risk.   Secretary of State Warren Christopher depicted the offer as a "deterrent force" that would have "both symbolic and tangible" value. But the decision raised questions about why they were needed and whether their presence might encourage rather than deter a Serbian attack on Macedonia, a former Yugoslav republic that has so far avoided involvement in the Balkan war.

nytimes_articles.headline: Screen Stars With Teeth to Spare
nytimes_articles.abstract: font size="-1" (June 11, 1993) "Jurassic Park" is a true movie milestone, presenting awe- and fear-inspiring sights never before seen on the screen.

nytimes_articles.headline: Art in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Alan Shields   Paula Cooper Gallery  149 Wooster Street  SoHo  Through Wednesday    Visiting a show of Alan Shields's work in the early 1970's was a little like camping out in paradise. His tie-dyed cloth hangings, with their bursts of soft vegetable colors, their mandalalike patterns and their delicate beadwork, were a kind of joyous hippie dream come true. Often free-hanging, they blurred the distinction between painting and sculpture, high art and low, and turned the dour minimalist grid into a malleable open-work design.

nytimes_articles.headline: Rabin, in Arab Interview, Offers U.S. Role in Vote
nytimes_articles.abstract: In the first interview given by an Israeli leader to a Palestinian newspaper, Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin was quoted today as saying members of the United States Congress may monitor future elections that would be held under Palestinian self-rule in Israeli-occupied territories.   Mr. Rabin also said Arabs in East Jerusalem might be allowed to vote in those elections, a significant statement in that Israel usually draws clear distinctions between Jerusalem and the territories, having declared it to be the country's unified capital. But even if given the vote, Jerusalem residents would not be able to run for office, he said.

nytimes_articles.headline: MEXICANS CAPTURE DRUG CARTEL CHIEF IN PRELATE'S DEATH
nytimes_articles.abstract: After an intense manhunt, federal police officials today announced the capture of one of Mexico's most powerful drug traffickers, whom they described as the target of a shootout last month in which a Roman Catholic cardinal was killed.    Government officials said the man arrested, Joaquin Guzman Loera, was seized by the Guatemalan authorities before dawn on Wednesday just south of the Mexican border, along with five of his closest associates.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.N. to Weigh Options on Bosnia Border Monitors
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Security Council unanimously adopted a resolution today asking Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali to prepare a report on "options for the possible deployment of international observers" to verify that Serbia is keeping its promise to cut off military aid to the Bosnian Serbs.   But the Council's decision remains an empty gesture that is unlikely to bring any action soon, because President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia has refused to allow such monitors into his republic.

nytimes_articles.headline: New York in Line to Direct the Peace Corps
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton is expected to nominate Carol Bellamy, former president of New York's City Council, as director of the Peace Corps, Administration officials said today.   Ms. Bellamy, now an investment banker for Bear Stearns, was unavailable for comment, but Maureen Connelly, her spokeswoman, said: "She's had discussions about the directorship of the Peace Corps but cannot comment further."

nytimes_articles.headline: RUSSIANS SEEKING ARMS PACT CHANGE
nytimes_articles.abstract: Concerned about instability along Russia's southern frontier, Russian military officials have told the Clinton Administration that they would like to revise the treaty limiting conventional forces in Europe so they can put more forces in the region.   The Russian request was conveyed to Defense Secretary Les Aspin by Gen. Pavel E. Grachev, the Russian Defense Minister, when they met this week in Germany. But a senior Administration official said Washington was not interested in reopening the treaty, fearing that such a move might lead to a general unraveling of the accord.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Dance; A Display of Pyrotechnics By New Leads in 'Etudes'
nytimes_articles.abstract: Harald Lander's "Etudes" works its way up through classroom and concert ballet to a display of pyrotechnics that is heart-stopping in its speed and drive. It is a ballet for those who wait breathlessly for the "Rose Adagio" balances in "The Sleeping Beauty" or the 32 fouettes in "Swan Lake." But a cast of three new leads in "Etudes," presented by American Ballet Theater on Wednesday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House, brought a warmth and luster to the dance.    One expects technical expertise and sensitivity to style from Susan Jaffe and she delivered it here. The soft curve of her body and, in particular, the angling of her head and shoulders in the ballet's white section recalled that this is a work by a choreographer schooled in the Danish style. And Ms. Jaffe's sunny radiance and authority lent an extra measure of graciousness to the ballerina role. Charles Askegard's long legs and feet did astonishing things to his beats, in a role debut as the Danish cavalier. Mr. Askegard also stood out for the elegant lyricism of his arms, an ebullient attack and partnering that was as exquisitely attuned as ever to his ballerina.

nytimes_articles.headline: Port Agency Will Resume Set-Asides
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday resumed its program of earmarking a large share of its purchasing budget for businesses owned by minorities or women. The budget includes nearly a billion dollars a year in contracts for construction, equipment and services.   The authority, the biggest private contractor in the New York City region, took the action at yesterday's monthly meeting of its Board of Commissioners after its own studies found proof that minority and woman-owned businesses did not get a fair share of its contracts.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Art Market
nytimes_articles.abstract: Value of Contracts   The Sonnabend Gallery's much-talked-about lawsuit against the artist Peter Halley and the art dealer Larry Gagosian and his Gagosian Gallery was settled out of court last week. After all the attention the case has received, the yearlong matter ended with something of a whimper.    "My only regret after all this is that the issue of gallery-artist obligations still has not been better defined," said Mr. Halley. Mr. Gagosian said he was happy the case was over. "It was unpleasant," he said, "and I'm glad it's behind us now."

nytimes_articles.headline: Art in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Annette Messager   Josh Baer Gallery  476 Broome Street  SoHo  Through June 26    Dark images of mobs carrying the heads of aristocrats on poles are summoned up by Annette Messager's most ambitious work here, "Les Piques" (The Pikes). The piece includes 183 thin metal rods, from three to eight feet long, which lean against two walls of the gallery. Impaled on about half the rods are stuffed cloth forms that suggest parts of dolls; the other poles carry drawings, done in crayon or colored pencil and sealed in glass.

nytimes_articles.headline: The End Is in Sight : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Malcolm W. Browne's fascinating article, "The Limits of Existence" (Health/Science June 3), quotes Dr. J. Richard Gott 3d as predicting that the human race could survive for 5 million years or so. .May I voice the opinion of an ordinary perso

nytimes_articles.headline: There Goes the Street, There Goes the Team
nytimes_articles.abstract: Racism has its franchises, too. For the first half of the 20th century, major league baseball teams stayed put. From 1950 to 1970, 10 of the 16 original clubs relocated, mostly to other cities, and the determining factor in the move seemed to have been the tilting of the neighborhood around the ball park from white to black.   The statistics that support this theory were presented yesterday to the fifth Cooperstown Symposium on Baseball and the American Culture by Professors Alan Sager and Arthur Culbert of the Boston University Schools of Public Health and Medicine. "We'd been studying urban hospitals," said Sager, "and we found that race was the biggest predictor of hospital relocations and closings. People are remarkably sanguine about such wholesale hospital closings although they are personal catastrophes. Baseball teams moving may not be so catastrophic, but they certainly offer dramatic episodes of this important phenomenon."

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Music; A Neglected Cole Porter Show With an Indestructible Song
nytimes_articles.abstract: Cole Porter's "Gay Divorce" appeared on Broadway in 1932, had a London production in 1933 and a movie version in 1934. "Night and Day," its principal song, has become the common property of street-corner hummers and shower-bath tenors: a near-indestructible artifact salvaged from an otherwise neglected show. Porter's comic stew of wisecracking Americans and vague Britons ran for 248 performances in New York, closing presumably because people stopped wanting to see it.   There is something both sad and invigorating about this adherence to supply and demand. For in order to understand the show's irresistible energy, one must first examine its need to succeed. "Gay Divorce" bursts with the desire to sell tickets and make audiences happy. In contrast is the current world of subsidized opera where audiences pay only a fraction of the bills and public and private begging make up the rest.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: She is a Federal district judge, one of the youngest in New York State, and she was almost the United States Attorney General. Now, 28 years after graduating from Connecticut College, KIMBA WOOD has become a member of Phi Beta Kappa.   The honor was bestowed upon her on Wednesday evening at a cocktail party for graduates of the New London, Conn., college. The party was at the New York apartment of JOANNE TOOR CUMMINGS, class of 1950, who told Judge Wood, "When you graduated from Connecticut College, something was forgotten."

nytimes_articles.headline: Landfill Operators Plead Guilty To Taking State Property on L.I.
nytimes_articles.abstract: Two landfill operators pleaded guilty today to appropriating 25 acres of state land at the edge of the Pilgrim Psychiatric Center in Brentwood and turning it into a sand mine and dump for construction and demolition debris.   The illegal operation continued for more than a decade despite fines and the operators' promises to stop. Authorities estimated that almost $1 million worth of sand and gravel was stolen.

nytimes_articles.headline: White Man's Burden : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: I wish to take to task mildly Mr. William Safire. In "Getting to the Core of the Matter" (Language, June 7), he refers to Rudyard Kipling's "Mandalay" and to that poet's "stiff-upper-lip, white-man's-burden support for the Britis

nytimes_articles.headline: Art in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Orshi Drozdik   Tom Cugliani Gallery  40 Wooster Street  SoHo  Through June 26    Orshi Drozdik's installation is based on some of the most frequently encountered themes of current art -- the vulnerability of the body, the duplicity of science, desire as an existential state -- but still manages to make something suggestive of them.

nytimes_articles.headline: Services for Petrovic
nytimes_articles.abstract: A memorial service for Drazen Petrovic will be held in Manhattan at 7:30 P.M. on Monday at the Croatian Roman Catholic Church, 502 West 41st Street. Petrovic, who was a 28-year-old guard for the New Jersey Nets, died in a car accident in Germany last Monday.

nytimes_articles.headline: It's Not Too Late for Clinton to Get It Right
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Re "A History of Gergenism" (editorial, June 2) and "The Constant Hearts" by A. M. Rosenthal (column, June 1): Americans of my generation, children of the Depression years, who grew up during World War II and were very active and centrist Democrats, voted for President Clinton because we believed he was an intelligent and practical professional politician who had learned from his McGovern activist days and his governorsip of Arkansas that we as a nation are people of the center. Many of us had voted for Ronald Reagan and George Bush in 1988 because we did not agree with the ideology of the Democratic Party or feel represented by its shrill, often faddish culture. We voted for President Clinton.   I am at a loss to understand how this intelligent man could have misunderstood the "centrist" message he conveyed during the campaign and made a first priority of the sexual roles of military personnel; then the firing of the travel bureau of the White House in what appeared to be a failure of due process, and then getting a haircut in a plane on a runway while holding up traffic.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Theater; Reviving an Intimate Musical With Romantic Intentions
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE first time I ever walked out of a Broadway show was to see "She Loves Me" a second time. It was Christmas week of 1963, and "She Loves Me," a sensitive flower among hard-edged comic blockbusters like "A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum" and "How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying," was surely a goner with the New Year. It was now or never. I bolted out of the 2 o'clock matinee of another flop (remember "Jennie," anyone?) to take one last look at "She Loves Me" at 3.   Though I didn't know much about anything else in 1963, time has borne out my youthful infatuation with "She Loves Me." The proof is at the Roundabout Theater Company, where this musical has finally received the exquisite revival of its fans' dreams and where surely new fans will soon be made by the legion. An intimate work with nothing on its sophisticated mind other than romance, "She Loves Me" is no less an anomaly on Broadway today than it was 30 years ago. Given how the world has aged since then, audiences may be hungrier than ever for this summons to a continuously melodic evening of sheer enchantment and complete escape.

nytimes_articles.headline: If Roles Were Reversed : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding Japan's continuing trade surplus with the United States, I wonder what the American attitude would be if the United States had the trade surplus? .Would Americans be any more willing than the Japanese to reduce the trade gap? Probably not. Th

nytimes_articles.headline: Ruling Scuttles Plan to Collect Taxes on Reservation Sales
nytimes_articles.abstract: New York State's highest court outlawed a state plan today that was intended to help the state collect taxes on the sale of gasoline and cigarettes by Indian retailers to non-Indian customers.   The unanimous decision killed a State Department of Taxation plan intended to do two things: collect as much as $100 million in unpaid taxes and force up prices on Indian reservations, where sales by tax-free stores to non-Indians are booming.

nytimes_articles.headline: Deposed Head of Empire Is Criticized for Severance
nytimes_articles.abstract: The New York State Insurance Superintendent said yesterday that Albert A. Cardone, the deposed head of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, has severance agreements that could cost the financially troubled company $2 million.   In a letter to the company's board, the superintendent, Salvatore A. Curiale, urged Empire not to pay.

nytimes_articles.headline: Yankees Get Their Captain Back
nytimes_articles.abstract: Don Mattingly is the Yankee captain, he occupies the coveted third spot in the batting order and teammates speak glowingly of his work habits. He returned to the lineup tonight for the first time since May 13, trying to help revive a team that had lost four of six games on this road trip without him.   Although Mattingly's return from a strained rib-cage muscle was treated with excitement by Manager Buck Showalter, Mattingly treated it indifferently.

nytimes_articles.headline: Article 493293 -- No Title
nytimes_articles.abstract: Many Indian restaurants in Manhattan seem to be taking the route of neighborhood Chinese restaurants, capitalizing on the delivery needs of the borough's residents and developing a solid repertory of satisfying but familiar dishes. However profitable this may be to restaurants, one result is a numbing sameness. Not only is one restaurant's tandoori chicken barely distinguishable from another's, but menus themselves also begin to appear interchangeable.   So it is a pleasure to find a restaurant like the six-week-old Al Hamra, which stands out not so much for the quality of its cooking -- although the food is fresh and lively -- as for the incredible value it offers. Nothing here costs more than $5. And that $5 (assuming you splurge on the most expensive dishes) buys portions that may take care of lunch tomorrow as well as dinner tonight.

nytimes_articles.headline: NAFTA as Process : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding "A NAFTA, but With Europe" (Opinion, May 25): .Lane Kirkland is quite right to argue that the North American Free Trade Agreement, conceived by the U.S., Canadian and Mexican governments, is more likely to provide quick profits for

nytimes_articles.headline: No Headline
nytimes_articles.abstract: "The more often you ask young children to think about something, the easier it becomes for them to make something up that they think is a memory." -- DR. STEPHEN CECI, a psychologist at Cornell University.  [ A23:3. ]

nytimes_articles.headline: Space Station's Reliance On Shuttle Is Questioned
nytimes_articles.abstract: A White House advisory committee says that the new options for a scaled-back space station depend too much on the space shuttle and that NASA should use unmanned rockets to carry the heaviest parts.   In a report delivered to the White House today, the independent panel said it was too risky to depend upon the shuttle as the sole launching vehicle. It recommended using a rocket like the Russian Proton, European Ariane 5, or American Titan 4.

nytimes_articles.headline: It's Not Too Late for Clinton to Get It Right; Alternative Budget
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   With all due respect, you seem to miss the point of the alternative budget plan I introduced with Senators John C. Danforth of Missouri, William S. Cohen of Maine and J. Bennett Johnston of Louisiana. "A Deal on the Economic Plan" (editorial, June 3) and other editorials level the charge that it was just oil state senators out to protect that industry.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Gas Tax Isn't Broad Enough
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton's B.T.U. tax is dead, killed by rising opposition in Congress. But the Clinton budget plan can still survive if Administration supporters in the Senate pursue a simpler energy tax that will do what the B.T.U. tax couldn't -- raise tens of billions without triggering crippling opposition by American manufacturers.   A flawed alternative comes from Senator John Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, who proposes to tax transportation fuels rather than all forms of energy. The Breaux tax, which is gaining support in the Senate Finance Committee, would fall primarily on gasoline for cars and trucks. And a gas tax, no matter what it's called, is unlikely to pass Congress because it strikes disproportionately at the West and rural areas where people drive long distances.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Photography; The Camera as a Weapon to Assault Modern Ills
nytimes_articles.abstract: It may seem a bit behind the curve, but the International Center of Photography has discovered the 1980's. That, at least, is the impression one gets from "Commodity Image," the sprawling, preachy muddle of a show at the center's midtown branch through July 18.    "Commodity Image" is based on the idea, widespread among artists and critics in the 80's, that images in advertising and the mass media not only influence people's opinions, but also determine the way they behave and think. Thus, it features work by Cindy Sherman, Laurie Simmons, Richard Prince, Louise Lawler and other artists, labeled post-modernist or appropriationist, who came to prominence in the 1980's with work that implicitly criticized the distortions of the mass media. Also included are pictures by photographers like Barbara Norfleet, JoAnn Verburg, John Pfahl and Lee Friedlander, who are not usually considered in this context.

nytimes_articles.headline: Discharge of Lesbian Urged by Navy Panel
nytimes_articles.abstract: A Navy board recommended today that a reserve officer be honorably discharged for being a lesbian, despite her lawyers' argument that the action violated a Federal judge's ruling made last winter.   Lieut. Zoe Dunning, a 29-year-old reserve supply officer, announced her homosexuality at a rally in January because, she said, she expected President Clinton to lift the military's ban on homosexuals. She said after the decision today: "It's difficult to be put on trial for who you are. My service record had no input."

nytimes_articles.headline: For Children
nytimes_articles.abstract: Metrotech Center   Jay Street at Myrtle Avenue  Downtown Brooklyn  Recommended ages: 4 and up    The Metrotech Center is a $1 billion complex that has changed the Brooklyn skyline, with its Chase Manhattan logo now glowing at night, and is meant to represent the borough's renaissance. Children who like to keep track of the city's goings-on and see some unusual art at the same time might want to visit Metrotech.

nytimes_articles.headline: 1918: Turkish Losses : IN OUR PAGES: 100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: LONDON - The War Office, in a communiqué regarding the operations in Palestine, states that on the morning of June 9 British troops, in the sector of the coast, executed an operation in detail which was crowned with success. They captured a part of t

nytimes_articles.headline: O'Brien Set Back by Infection
nytimes_articles.abstract: DAN O'BRIEN, the world-record holder in the decathlon, has a prostate infection that could hamper his performance at the USA-Mobil Outdoor Track and Field Championships at Eugene, Ore., next week.   His coach, MIKE KELLER, said yesterday by telephone that O'Brien missed five days of workouts and would not get back onto the track at the University of Oregon until Tuesday, the opening of the decathlon competition.

nytimes_articles.headline: Abroad at Home; Racism Lives
nytimes_articles.abstract: Is it time for the Federal Government to ease up on enforcing the right to vote in areas of the country that have a history of discrimination against black voters?    That question lurked behind the fight over Lani Guinier's nomination as Assistant Attorney General. Some of her opponents -- not most, but some who mattered -- would answer yes.

nytimes_articles.headline: Answers Still Needed On Crown Heights
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "Crown Heights Was Not Iasi" by Joyce Purnick (Editorial Notebook, June 3) stated of the events that took place in Brooklyn in the summer of 1991: "Police protection was inadequate, to put it mildly. Why?"   It is clear that irrespective of investigations undertaken by the Federal and state governments and a private lawsuit, that the New York City Council has the responsibility to look into the horrendous attack on the Jewish residents of Crown Heights.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sports of The Times; Amid Ashes In Bullpen, Gooden Glows
nytimes_articles.abstract: HALF an hour after Dwight Gooden raised his record to 7-4 last Monday night for a Mets team that has won only 19 games, Al Harazin walked into Dallas Green's office.   "Gooden tomorrow, Gooden Wednesday, Saberhagen Thursday," the Mets general manager said, smiling. "Then Gooden Friday, Gooden Saturday . . . "'

nytimes_articles.headline: I Can't Believe I Went to the Prom
nytimes_articles.abstract: I know that many people, especially New Agers, have much more transcendental, significant realizations, but I still can't believe that I went to the prom. I thought that the prom only happened in a place called Teen World, where girls my age budget their time between pep squad, fawning over pictures of Doogie Howser and being upstanding citizens.   I learned about Teen World from magazines, movies and sit-coms. It is a realm where skimpy clothes, a body to wear them and a boy to appreciate both are the holy trinity. To have different priorities is virtually unheard of. Luckily, in Teen World, girls who look darn near anorexic always seem tremendously happy. They also seem to be free from the street harassment that wearing, say, the low-cut body suit that YM magazine recommends as date wear this month tends to incur. And in Teen World, there is never a contradiction between a near-reverent focus on boys and a subtle but equally intense emphasis on the sanctity of virginity.

nytimes_articles.headline: THE ARTS GUIDE
nytimes_articles.abstract: AUSTRIA. Vienna . ufaggallKunsthistorisches Museum (tel: 52.177). To June 27: "Die Welt der Maya." More than 300 objects explore the world of the Mayas which spans Belize, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras and Mexico.. Osterreichisches Museum f&#

nytimes_articles.headline: The Essence of Italian Pop Culture
nytimes_articles.abstract: Narrator (off camera):"And in the sprawling Pampas, where pistols make the law, the mysterious Caballero searches for the woman who has inflamed his heart. A voice rings out across the Pampas:'Does Carmencita live here? '"

nytimes_articles.headline: Restaurants
nytimes_articles.abstract: On soft spring evenings La Metairie sparkles like a seductive beacon in the heart of the West Village, its white-trimmed windows swung open to reveal candlelight, white walls with wooden beams and cheerful Provencal colors. La Metairie may well be the most romantic restaurant downtown, and better yet, you don't need to be an Onassis heir to enjoy it.   La Metairie (the name means small cooperative farm) once held the distinction of being one of the smallest white-tablecloth restaurants in Manhattan, with fewer than two dozen seats in one barnlike room. In 1991 the owner, Sylvain Fareri, renovated an adjacent grocery store and more than doubled the seating while maintaining the enchanting Provencal farmhouse look. Stuccolike white walls have dark wood trim and hold farm utensils; firewood is stacked on overhead ledges; banquettes and chairs are covered with sunny Provencal fabrics, and candlelight gives it all an enchanting glow. No wonder you see so many couples holding hands there.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sounds Around Town
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Freshmen on Tour   Four Freshmen, Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue at 17th Street, (212) 533-7900. The Four Freshmen, the group of singing instrumentalists discovered by Stan Kenton in Dayton, Ohio, in 1950, are going strong after 43 years. Except for Bob Flanigan, the group's leader, who at 66 still sings and plays trombone, the group is now made up of relative youngsters. But the presence of Mr. Flanigan assures that such old Freshmen favorites as "It's a Blue World" and "Day In, Day Out" are still performed with the group's original harmonic flair, even though there has been a fifth Freshman for several years. At Fat Tuesday's, which has been a regular stop on Freshmen tours for more than 10 years, they will go on tonight and tomorrow night at 8, 10 and midnight; on Sunday at 8 and 10 P.M. There is a $20 music charge and a $10 minimum.  A Blossom Dearie Series    Blossom Dearie, the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street, Chelsea, (212) 244-3005. Blossom Dearie, the singer and pianist whose voice is an astonishing mixture of little-girl innocence and dark throatiness, has been playing twilight performances at the Ballroom off and on since 1984. Originally they were a winter series, but now she has become a summertime attraction, playing Fridays and Saturdays at 6:30 P.M. Her repertory is a very special mixture of sophisticated wit and nimble rhythm created partly by such old hands as Cole Porter and Noel Coward but leaning more toward contemporary songwriters: Dave Frishberg, John Wallowitch and Miss Dearie herself. Accompanied by the bassist Ray Kilday, she plays a single extended set at 6:30 P.M. today and tomorrow. There is a $15 music charge and a two-drink minimum.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Name and a Date For Letterman Show
nytimes_articles.abstract: David Letterman cannot take the title "Late Night" with him when he moves to CBS this summer because it belongs to NBC. But he will be doing the next best thing, CBS announced yesterday. He will call his new program "Late Show."    The show will have its premiere on Aug. 30, the network said, and will run Mondays through Fridays from 11:35 P.M. to 12:35 A.M.

nytimes_articles.headline: LAWSUIT BY PRIEST CHARGES SEX ABUSE
nytimes_articles.abstract: A parish priest and two other men who say they were sexually abused by priests when they were children today sued Roman Catholic Church leaders under the Federal Racketeering Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act.   The suit in Federal District Court in neighboring Camden, N.J., is the first time the RICO statue has been invoked against church officials or in a sexual abuse case, according to legal experts. The Rev. Gary R. Hayes, one of the plaintiffs, is also the first priest to sue church officials for childhood sexual abuse by another.

nytimes_articles.headline: Record Low Dropout Rate Is Met With Skepticism
nytimes_articles.abstract: Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez yesterday reported the lowest dropout rate ever recorded in New York City, a rate far lower than that reported by virtually all other large urban school systems in the country.   It was the fourth consecutive year of declining dropout rates, and Mr. Fernandez, who leaves office at the end of the month, attributed the success largely to changes he introduced during his stormy three-and-a-half-year tenure as Chancellor.

nytimes_articles.headline: Last Chance
nytimes_articles.abstract: Here is a sampling of shows in New York City that close soon: Closing This Weekend  "SOMEONE WHO'LL WATCH OVER ME," Booth Theater, 222 West 45th Street, Manhattan. A drama by Frank McGuinness about three men being held captive in Beirut. Through Sunday. Performances: Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2 and 8 P.M.; Sunday at 3 P.M. Tickets: $40 to $45. Information: (212) 239-6200. "AVENUE X," Playwrights Horizons, New Theater Wing Studio, 416 West 42d Street, Clinton. An a cappella musical by John Jiler and Ray Leslee, set in the early 1960's, about two young singers who try to take an interracial act to the old Fox Theater in Brooklyn. Through Sunday. Performances: Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 3 and 8 P.M.; Sunday at 2 and 7 P.M. Tickets: $5. Information: (212) 279-4200.

nytimes_articles.headline: Books of The Times; Reality Infused With Intimations of the Divine
nytimes_articles.abstract: Sister Water   By Nancy Willard   255 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $21.     In her enchanting first novel, "Things Invisible to See" (1985), the poet and children's author Nancy Willard conjured up a magical world in which the mundane and the metaphysical merged and overlapped. Here, the dead played baseball with the living, vacuum cleaners picked up gold jewelry and gold fillings, and emissaries from the spirit world introduced human beings to a realm of things invisible to see. As in a child's book of fairy tales, transactions between the real and the fantastic occurred with almost offhand nonchalance, not as manifestations of an irrational cosmos, but as intimations of a divinely ordered realm in which change and metamorphosis are part of the redemptive cycle of life.

nytimes_articles.headline: Belmont Stewards Suspend Migliore
nytimes_articles.abstract: Belmont Park stewards have suspended RICHARD MIGLIORE for seven calendar days for careless riding aboard Game Wager in Monday's second race. The suspension, handed down Wednesday, will begin Saturday and keep Migliore idle through June 18. (AP)

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. and North Koreans Press Nuclear Talks
nytimes_articles.abstract: The United States and North Korea failed again last night to resolve a dispute over Pyongyang's nuclear weapons program, but representatives of the two countries were to meet today in a last-ditch effort to reach agreement on the issue.   With North Korea's withdrawal from the treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons to take effect tomorrow, American officials said they may have no alternative but to turn to the United Nations for help in compelling Pyongyang to rejoin the accord and open its nuclear sites for inspection.

nytimes_articles.headline: Administration Decides F.B.I. Chief Must Leave, Officials Say
nytimes_articles.abstract: Five months after a scalding report on his conduct, the Clinton Administration has concluded that William S. Sessions should step down as Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and has begun negotiations with his lawyers to ease him from office, Government officials said today.   In conversations this week, Justice Department officials and lawyers for Mr. Sessions have weighed his narrowing options, five and a half years into a 10-year term as Director.

nytimes_articles.headline: NEWS SUMMARY
nytimes_articles.abstract: International A3-11  MEXICO CAPTURES SUSPECT  After an intense manhunt, Mexican police announced the capture of one of Mexico's most powerful cocaine traffickers and said he would be charged in connection with killing a Roman Catholic Cardinal.  A1  MACEDONIA TO GET U.S. TROOPS  The United States said it would send 300 peacekeeping troops to Macedonia to help contain the Bosnian war. Secretary of State Warren Christopher depicted the offer as a "deterrent force." A1

nytimes_articles.headline: Cambodian Rulers Reject Election Results
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Government, rejecting election results that show its political party the loser in last month's elections, warned today that some provinces would try to secede from Cambodia rather than come under the control of the royalist opposition party that won at the polls.   The leader of the huge United Nations peacekeeping operation in Cambodia, Yasushi Akashi, said at a news conference that "dissidents" within the government were angry over the election results and were "demonstrating their unhappiness by moving for the establishment of some kind of autonomous region in the east and northeastern part of Cambodia."

nytimes_articles.headline: Art in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: 'Alberto Giacometti: Sculpture'  Gagosian Gallery 980 Madison Avenue (at 77th Street) Manhattan Through June 19    Few artists made postwar existential angst as credibly manifest as Alberto Giacometti. His recipe included aspects of Cycladic and Egyptian art -- notably frontality and simplification -- mixed with an agitated, ingeniously varied surface and a sense of the individual that was strictly modern.

nytimes_articles.headline: Governor and N.Y.R.A. to Air Dispute
nytimes_articles.abstract: The dispute between Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the people who operate horse racing in New York State took a new turn yesterday when the Governor invited the 23 trustees of the New York Racing Association to meet with him next week to explore the issues between them.   But the Governor's tax chief, meanwhile, kept the dispute alive by demanding that the racing association immediately pay its past-due tax bill of $1.9 million. The tax commissioner, James W. Wetzler, said in a strong letter that the state would not wait for the racing association to pay the bill at the present rate of $200,000 a week. The bill originally totalled $4 million, but the association made a lump payment of $2 million two weeks ago.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mashburn Goes Public, Stock Soars
nytimes_articles.abstract: Jamal Mashburn seemed a little overwhelmed yesterday. There he was, a 20-year-old standing on a schoolyard court on the Upper West Side. Behind him, a brand-new cherry-red Ferrari, fans, cameras, police officers, microphones, and a throng of kids mobbing him for his signature.   "You know you're popular when somebody asks you for an autograph in New York City," said the soft-spoken Harlem native who figures to be among the top three picks in the June 30th National Basketball Association draft. "I guess I'm a public figure now."

nytimes_articles.headline: Young Toughs of Fuk Ching Gang Mourn 4
nytimes_articles.abstract: The four coffins lay open. Fifteen young men in loose-fitting double-breasted black suits, black ties and wrap-around sunglasses walked past them in silence, some bowing slightly.   The men in the coffins were young, too, and dressed identically in black suits, except for one with a favorite Yankees baseball cap placed on his head. They were all members of the Fuk Ching, law-enforcement officials said, a Chinatown gang linked to the smuggling of illegal aliens, including those aboard the ship that ran aground in Queens early Sunday.

nytimes_articles.headline: Rescue Team, Earn New Contract
nytimes_articles.abstract: JOHN LUCAS, who took over as San Antonio coach early last season and led the Spurs to a second-place finish in the National Basketball Association's Midwest Division, signed a four-year contract yesterday.   Terms of the pact were not disclosed.

nytimes_articles.headline: It's Not Too Late for Clinton to Get It Right; Persistent Slant
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Among my friends, and increasingly for me, a concern has been growing that The New York Times has in some sense sold out. To whom? I cannot say; indeed, I have no idea. But we have all become increasingly shocked and troubled by the flagrant editorializing on your front page and in particular by what seems to have developed into a "get Clinton" obsession in your editorials and columns.

nytimes_articles.headline: Powell Receives a Rousing Greeting at Harvard
nytimes_articles.abstract: Instead of the threatened noisy protests against the military's ban on homosexuals, Gen. Colin L. Powell, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, drew a rousing ovation today from Harvard University students, faculty and alumni at commencement ceremonies here.    Many of the Harvard graduates took issue with General Powell as a symbol of the military's opposition to homosexuals serving openly in the ranks, but it was generally a quiet protest. Hundreds of students held placards or pink balloons emblazoned with "Lift the Ban" that bobbed lazily in the tree-shaded Harvard Yard during a morning ceremony. Scores of students and some faculty members turned their backs on the general when he received an honorary degree of law.

nytimes_articles.headline: 1943: Island Battle : IN OUR PAGES: 100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA - [From our New York edition:] American airmen laid explosives across Pantelleria's scarred face again yesterday [June 9], tore up two Sicilian airfields near volcanic Mt. Etna, and won a 39-1 aerial victory at those in

nytimes_articles.headline: Diner's Journal
nytimes_articles.abstract: Indies   Indies is part of the new wave of Caribbean-style restaurants washing over Manhattan. Its pre-opening publicity described it as a West Indies restaurant and nightclub with a tropical rain forest decor, including "four active waterfalls surrounded by tropical plants and foliage, shell-shaped sconces, hemp-wrapped railings, slow-moving ceiling fans and an outrageous sound system."   The main dining room of Indies is colorful and cheerful, although the giant bandstand takes up about a fourth of the space. The so-called waterfalls look like something you would see at a shopping mall, a series of pink cement pools fed by foot-long turquoise sluices. Upstairs has a bar and more tables.

nytimes_articles.headline: THE MOVIE GUIDE : Jonah Who Lived in the Whale
nytimes_articles.abstract: Directed by Roberto Faenza. Italy-France. .Based on the autobiography of Jonah Oberski, Roberto Faenza's film tells the story of a family of Dutch Jews deported from their home in Amsterdam to the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp. It is a story that has

nytimes_articles.headline: Wickman Blocks Out Bikers and Brewers
nytimes_articles.abstract: The distractions could have destroyed Bob Wickman and transformed the first start in his home state into a disaster. There were 24 tickets to secure, the threat of a renewed beanball war between two teams that despise each other, the return of Don Mattingly, two more Yankee injuries and, just in case that was not enough, 6,000 Harley-Davidson motorcycle enthusiasts in town for a convention and cheering the Brewers.   Enough to cloud his mind? Apparently not.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Example of Cyprus : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding "Standing Aside in Self-Deluding Virtue" (Opinion, June 1): .Peter Schneider seems to believe Cyprus is an example of a peacekeeping operation that works. Unfortunately it has only perpetuated the aggressor's territorial and "e

nytimes_articles.headline:
Condominium Development;
Recession-Thwarted Project Reborn
nytimes_articles.abstract:
For five years the real estate recession has thwarted plans to transform a 13.5-acre site along Ridgedale Avenue here into housing. But now, a backhoe is tearing into the earth in preparation for putting up 165 condominiums.

Westminster Homes Inc., a subsidiary of the Kushner Companies, both of Florham Park, N.J., has taken over the project, which was conceived by a group of local developers who pulled out in the face of a gloomy market. Westminster has redesigned the units and will deliver them at prices designed to woo cost-conscious consumers.

nytimes_articles.headline: Reaganomics, With a Mexican Accent
nytimes_articles.abstract: The growing opposition in Congress to the North American Free Trade Agreement may save the Administration from its own confusion.   The President has ignored the contradiction between his ambitious program for domestic revitalization and his support for a much freer flow of capital and labor between the United States and Mexico. The trade agreement and continuing high levels of immigration from Mexico can derail his vision of a high-investment, high-wage, high-tech America.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mastercard and Midtown: City Hall Wins in New Tack
nytimes_articles.abstract: In a decision that company officials say turned more on New York City's intangible assets than on simple economics, Mastercard International will keep its headquarters in mid-Manhattan rather than move to Westchester County.   For the city, Mastercard's decision to move from its current Manhattan headquarters into nine floors of the old Burlington House on the Avenue of the Americas means holding onto 450 jobs, and if Mastercard's own growth projections hold true, getting another 750 within the next 12 years.

nytimes_articles.headline: On Stage, and Off
nytimes_articles.abstract: 'Sunset Boulevard' Postponement    A bizarre technical snafu has forced Andrew Lloyd Webber to cancel several previews of "Sunset Boulevard" in London and postpone the openingof the musical from June 29 until July 12.   According to a statement issued yesterday by Mr. Lloyd Webber, the production was two weeks behind schedule because newly installed hydraulic valves, necessary for moving scenery around on stage, were faulty. A New York press representative for the show, Peter Brown, explained further that the valves, which are radio operated, proved "susceptible to interference from every cellular phone in London." Unable to find the problem, the suppliers simply had to remove the new valves and put the old ones back. The work has kept the cast from rehearsing on stage.

nytimes_articles.headline: Screen Stars With Teeth to Spare
nytimes_articles.abstract: Steven Spielberg's "Jurassic Park" is a true movie milestone, presenting awe- and fear-inspiring sights never before seen on the screen. The more spectacular of these involve the fierce, lifelike dinosaurs that stalk through the film with astounding ease. Much scarier, however, are those aspects of "Jurassic Park" that establish it as the overnight flagship of a brand-new entertainment empire. Even while capturing the imagination of its audience, this film lays the groundwork for the theme-park rides, sequels and souvenirs that insure the "Jurassic Park" experience will live on. And on. And on.

nytimes_articles.headline: Ex-Cowboy Holt Signs With Dolphins
nytimes_articles.abstract: Cornerback ISSIAC HOLT, a starter the past three seasons for the Dallas Cowboys, signed as a free agent yesterday with the Miami Dolphins.

nytimes_articles.headline: Germany And Brazil Battle to Stalemate
nytimes_articles.abstract: Brazil was Brazil for the first half, dashing and deceptive on the way to a three-goal lead. Germany was Germany for the second, persistent and efficient in its meticulous comeback.   The result today at steamy Robert F. Kennedy Stadium was a 3-3 tie in the U.S. Cup tournament, a stylistic stalemate between two national soccer teams that could very well meet next summer in the final of the 1994 World Cup.

nytimes_articles.headline: Florio Bars Blind Trusts for State's Top Officials
nytimes_articles.abstract: Gov. Jim Florio issued an executive order today that will eliminate the use of blind trusts by top state employees. The order is intended to stop New Jersey officials from using blind trusts to shield assets that would otherwise be subject to conflict-of-interest scrutiny.   The order would also prohibit companies owned by the workers -- senior officials of the executive branch and others appointed by the Governor -- from doing business with government at any level, from Federal to local.

nytimes_articles.headline: Art in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: 'An American Vision: Vintage F.S.A. Photographs, 1935-1943'   Howard Greenberg Gallery  120 Wooster Street (near Prince Street)  SoHo  Through June 19    The work of the photographers attached to the Farm Security Administration during the Depression remains a landmark in the history of documentary photography. Formed to provide publicity for the New Deal agency, the photographic unit, under the often heavy-handed direction of Roy Stryker, gradually expanded its focus to encompass many aspects of American society.

nytimes_articles.headline: Wanted: Contributors in Search of Immortality
nytimes_articles.abstract: Call it an answer to the yearning for immortality: for a price, universities and colleges will carve the name of a generous benefactor in limestone on an imposing building. Too costly? The donor can opt for a piece of the building -- a student lounge, a science laboratory, a library, even a photography darkroom -- dedicated in perpetuity with a bronze plaque.   The practice of marketing buildings and other campus landmarks is hardly new, but it is reaching new dimensions. Squeezed between faltering government support and rising expenses, private universities and colleges are pursuing potential donors as never before, with lists of "naming opportunities" ranging from research institutes to plastic seats in an athletic stadium.

nytimes_articles.headline: Plan Seeks To Rebuild Downtown Of the Bronx
nytimes_articles.abstract: Gambling that an infusion of public money will reverse 25 years of decline, state, city and Bronx officials announced yesterday an ambitious plan to rebuild the Bronx's downtown. They said the plan was aimed at encouraging private investment in the borough and keeping the Yankees in the Bronx.   The officials, announcing a proposal developed through Borough President Fernando Ferrer's office, admitted they had no guarantees on financing. Rather, they said, the plan was intended as a framework for rebuilding the area around four huge public projects in the next decade at an estimated cost of $1 billion.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mets Go From 5 Runs Up to 21 1/2 Games Behind
nytimes_articles.abstract: The cruelest part of the home run was that it refused to come down. On and on it carried. Shea Stadium, long ago conditioned to calamity, was forced to wait for the final crash.   There was no sound, though, for the baseball wound up too far gone to even be tracked. It cleared bleachers and outer walls and simply vanished. The Mets were gone soon after, their 5-0 lead twisted into a 7-6 defeat to the Phillies.

nytimes_articles.headline: Can't Hear Whistle Blowing, Can You?
nytimes_articles.abstract: Michael Jordan may or may not have lost $1.2 million betting on golf, but the bottom-line figure for David Stern and the rest of the National Basketball Association yesterday was 16.8. That's what Game 1 of the league finals drew as a rating for the network Wednesday night, the commissioner was happy to announce.   If only Michael Jordan's gambling explanations rated that high.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: An obituary yesterday about Gabriel Preil, an American poet and translator skilled in Hebrew who died on Saturday at 82, omitted a survivor. He is Mr. Preil's brother, Joseph Kushner of Brooklyn.

nytimes_articles.headline: It's Pee Wee's Brooklyn Adventure
nytimes_articles.abstract: Mark Reese has "hung around" a father and retired shortstop named Pee Wee for 36 years down home in Louisville, Ky. The filmmaker grew up with tales of daddy and the Duke, Jackie and Gil, Campy and Newk: the entire course catalogue of the Brooklyn Dodgers from the early 1940's to the late 1950's.   About a year ago, Reese detoured from producing a film about Cooperstown and the Baseball Hall of Fame to one solely about his father, "Pee Wee Reese: The Quiet Ambassador," a project that will grow into individual films about Roy Campanella, Duke Snider, Jackie Robinson, Sandy Koufax and Don Drysdale.

nytimes_articles.headline: Japan: A Win-Win Solution to the Trade Problem
nytimes_articles.abstract: The writer is deputy secretary-general of Japan's Liberal Democratic Party and former vice minister of foreign affairs..At their summit meeting in April, Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa and President Bill Clinton agreed to create a new framework for U.

nytimes_articles.headline: AIDS LINK TO V.D. BECOMES CLEARER
nytimes_articles.abstract: Researchers at the ninth international meeting on AIDS said here today that they had a better understanding of why people with other sexually transmitted diseases are at much higher risk of being infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS.   Several experts said greater efforts against all sexually transmitted diseases would help curtail the spread of H.I.V. They pointed to the example of Sweden, where both sexually transmitted disease and reported H.I.V. infections are very low.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Bitter Past Sweetens The Cup for Demers
nytimes_articles.abstract: For the longest time, Jacques Demers was unwanted. There was the summer he sat in his house in Farmington Hills, Mich., and watched Cubs games on television, raked leaves in the yard, and tried not to think about the coming hockey season. There were all those wistful nights when he sat in a radio booth in Quebec and gave commentary on some other coach and his hockey team. There were the endless days when the telephone just didn't ring.   He was afraid, then, even to dream of this moment. Dropped by the Detroit Red Wings in 1990, treated like an outcast by National Hockey League general managers, Demers didn't know whether he'd ever get another chance to coach. And he certainly didn't think he would someday have this job: Coach of his hometown Montreal Canadiens, the most storied franchise in National Hockey League history, a team that he led to an unparalleled 24th Stanley Cup in his first year as head coach.

nytimes_articles.headline: NEW U.S. PROGRAM OF STUDENT LOANS CLEARS KEY PANEL
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee today approved a modified version of President Clinton's proposal to put the Federal Government in the business of lending money directly to college students.   The plan, which is now almost certain to be enacted in some form, is intended to cut costs both to students and to the Government, which now acts as a guarantor of student loans made by private financial institutions.

nytimes_articles.headline: We Listened, and Justice Marshall Talked
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "In Marshall Papers Case, Library Abuses Trust" (letters, June 3) and "Library of Congress -- or School for Scandal" (Op-Ed, May 27) claim the Library of Congress betrayed the intent of Justice Thurgood Marshall by opening his papers soon after his death last January. Unfair, untrue.

nytimes_articles.headline: Japan Opens Door Wider to Foreign Press
nytimes_articles.abstract: Breaking down a longtime barrier to the flow of information abroad, Japan's newspaper editors voted today to allow foreign journalists to join the exclusive press clubs that have jealously guarded access to Government officials and important corporate and financial data.   The action came as a number of non-Japanese news organizations were threatening to make a trade issue of the press club system.

nytimes_articles.headline: With Barkley, Grant Has a Tiger by the Tail
nytimes_articles.abstract: Horace Grant, the median strip between Charles Barkley and the basket, was still in one piece today. Assigned on Wednesday night to shadow Barkley, with absolutely no help, Grant never took his goggled eyes off of the Phoenix Suns' Goliath and was able to obstruct 16 of Barkley's spinning shots.   This afternoon, Grant did not know whether to gloat or run for cover. The Chicago Bulls, with Barkley out of their hair, turned Game 1 of this National Basketball Association championship series into a casual 100-92 victory, although a conglomerate of Bulls players have since tortured Grant with stormy predictions for Friday's Game 2.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Releases 4 of the Chinese Seized From Ship
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Immigration and Naturalization Service yesterday released four of the nearly 300 Chinese aliens seized after a freighter ran aground off a Queens beach on Sunday and said it would consider releasing others on a case-by-case basis pending hearings on their claims for asylum.   The move represented a turnaround by the agency, which had said earlier this week that it would keep all the aliens in detention as an example to other would-be immigrants and their smugglers.

nytimes_articles.headline: What they're reading
nytimes_articles.abstract: Lord Norwich, British author and broadcaster, is reading "Reckoning: The Murder of Christopher Marlowe," by Charles Nicholl. ."It's riveting - a wonderful bit of literary, historical detection. It's the whole world of English spies - a w

nytimes_articles.headline: Haiti: End the Charade
nytimes_articles.abstract: After 20 months of dithering, Washington finally seems to have summoned the political will to apply serious pressure for the restoration of democracy in Haiti.   The United States, Canada, Venezuela and France are preparing to ask the U.N. Security Council to slap a worldwide ban on oil shipments to Haiti, backed up by Chapter 7 of the U.N. Charter, which authorizes the use of military force. The oil embargo would reinforce a toothless Western Hemisphere economic embargo. And it would be accompanied by a new round of political negotiations timed to exploit Tuesday's resignation of Marc Bazin, the military's figurehead Prime Minister.

nytimes_articles.headline: Koch Backs Badillo for Comptroller on 'Fusion' Ticket
nytimes_articles.abstract: Former Mayor Edward I. Koch yesterday endorsed a fellow Democrat, Herman Badillo, for New York City comptroller, saying it would not "upset" him if this helped the Republican "fusion" ticket.    Mr. Koch, who had announced his support for Mr. Badillo as a mayoral candidate before Mr. Badillo dropped out of that race, said that he did not know who he would endorse for mayor now but that he expected to make a decision by September. Mr. Koch has hinted at the possibility of an endorsement of the Republican candidate, Rudolph W. Giuliani, against the Democratic incumbent, David N. Dinkins, and yesterday he did little to dispel that notion. A Multiparty Alliance    Asked by reporters during a news conference on the steps of City Hall whether he would be helping the Giuliani camp by standing behind Mr. Badillo, Mr. Koch answered, "If it happens, I'm not going to be upset."

nytimes_articles.headline: INSIDE
nytimes_articles.abstract: 4 Chinese Freed by U.S.   The Immigration and Naturalization Service released four of the Chinese who were aboard the freighter that ran aground off Queens. Page B1.    The deposed head of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield is said to have severance agreements totaling $2 million. Page B4. Bellamy for Peace Corps    President Clinton is expected to nominate Carol Bellamy, the former New York City Council President, as head of the Peace Corps. Page A16. Epidemic Tied to New Virus    A new or previously unrecognized virus is believed to be the cause of a mysterious epidemic of a flu-like illness in the Southwest. Page A14.

nytimes_articles.headline: Tracks of Mystery Disease Lead to New Form of Virus
nytimes_articles.abstract: As the death of a young Navajo woman dashed hopes that an epidemic of a flu-like illness had begun to abate in the Southwest, Federal health officials said yesterday that a new or previously unrecognized strain of virus may have caused the mysterious outbreak.    The woman, a 22-year-old from Gallup, N.M., died Wednesday night after being flown by helicopter to a hospital in Albuquerque for emergency treatment. Another recent death in the region was also attributed yesterday to the disease, bringing the tentative death toll to 14.

nytimes_articles.headline: THE MOVIE GUIDE : Madadayo
nytimes_articles.abstract: Directed by Akira Kurosawa. Japan. .The title is taken from the response in the game of hide-and-seek. "Moiikai?" ("Are you ready?") calls one child, and the answer is "Madadayo" ("Not yet"). This is also the resp

nytimes_articles.headline: RESULTS PLUS
nytimes_articles.abstract: COLLEGE BASEBALL  Wichita State Advances to Title Game  Freshman Casey Blake drove in five runs to lead Wichita State to a 10-4 victory over Oklahoma State yesterday and a berth in the championship game of the College World Series in Omaha. Tomorrow, seventh-seeded Wichita State (58-16) will be in its fourth championship game in six trips to the Division I baseball championships. The Shockers will play the winner of today's game between fifth-seeded Louisiana State (51-17-1) and fourth-seeded Long Beach State (46-18). The Shockers, who beat Oklahoma State 12-7 with a late rally in their regular-season meeting this year, took the lead early this time. Walks to Joey Adams, Richie Taylor and Darren Dreifort, his an intentional one with two out, set up Joey Jackson's two-run double in the third. Blake then drove in two with a single and Adam McCollough followed a single by Tommy Tilma with another single to drive in a fifth run off Cowboys starter Jake Benz (9-2). Joe Wallace doubled and Ernesto Rivera drove him home with a single in the bottom of the inning, but Wichita State matched that when Jackson walked with the bases loaded in the fourth. (AP) TENNIS  3 Big Names Move to Quarterfinals  Three former Wimbledon champions, Stefan Edberg of Sweden and Germans Boris Becker and Michael Stich, all advanced to the quarterfinals with victories yesterday at the Queen's Club grass-court championships in London. The second-seeded Edberg turned back a fierce third-set challenge from No. 15-seeded American Richey Reneberg to win by 7-6 (7-3), 3-6, 6-2. Edberg defeated Reneberg for the sixth time in seven meetings but did not gain control until he came back from 40-0 to break serve and take a 3-1 lead in the final set. Becker defeated the 14th-seeded Frenchman, Guillaume Raoux, by 6-4, 6-4, in 80 minutes. Stich marched past 12th-seeded David Wheaton of the United States, 6-4, 6-3. In another match, Grant Stafford, Wednesday's upset winner over top-ranked Pete Sampras, ended his run with a 6-4, 6-3 loss to No. 16 Marc Goellner. (AP) Shriver Rallies to Win: The former champion Pam Shriver found some of her former magic yesterday, recovering from a breakdown in the final set to defeat Mana Endo of Japan, 4-6, 7-6 (7-5), 6-4, at the women's grass-court championships at Edgbaston, England. Shriver, seeded No. 7, won the event from 1984-87. She fell behind by 3-1 in the third but fought back to win on her first match point when Endo netted a backhand. "I'm grateful I dug this match out," Shriver said. "This is the kind of player on grass I would have chewed up and spat out a few years ago." Second-seeded South African Amanda Coetzer joined Martina Navratilova on the sidelines after losing by 7-6 (7-1), 6-2 to Chanda Rubin, seeded 15th. Nathalie Tauziat of France is now the top-ranked player in the event. The third-seeded Tauziat progressed to the quarterfinals with a 6-3, 6-4 victory over Claire Wegink of the Netherlands. (AP)

nytimes_articles.headline: Two Downwind Holes Bring Kite to Earth
nytimes_articles.abstract: Weeks ago, Tom Kite was an immovable object. Now he is once again golf's irresistible force.   Unlike recent United States Open champions who found the trophy a psychological burden, Kite has played some of his best golf since winning at Pebble Beach 12 months ago. And in a matter of weeks, Kite has gone from being incapacitated by herniated disks to approaching top form for his Open defense next week at Baltusrol in Springfield, N.J.

nytimes_articles.headline: Hear This
nytimes_articles.abstract: Reflections while on hold at a dollar a minute: Voice mail is a dandy invention, right up there with the fax when it comes to communicating with folks without actually having to talk to them. But when the music coming back at you while you're waiting to

nytimes_articles.headline: Topics of The Times; Forcing Money on the Military
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Senate Appropriations Committee followed the House's lead this week and approved $1.2 billion in additional spending for the Pentagon. The money will be used for relief efforts in Somalia, health insurance for military families, the repair of storm-damaged Marine bases, air operations over Iraq and aid to the Kurds -- worthy causes all.    The odd thing is that the Pentagon didn't ask for the money. To pay for these causes, it was prepared to reprogram funds it didn't need, like $274 million to buy executive jets for the top brass and V.I.P.'s.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Dance; Offbeat Visions in Premieres by Two Companies
nytimes_articles.abstract: David Dorfman Dance and Shapiro and Smith Dance, two companies that can be counted upon for intelligent as well as inventive choreography, opened the Altogether Different season on Monday night with a stimulating program at the Joyce Theater.    Eight modern-dance organizations are participating in this series, which continues through June 19, and each performance features two groups.

nytimes_articles.headline: Folding an Era: Imagine Castro-less Convertibles
nytimes_articles.abstract: NO one, but no one, demonstrates a sofa bed like Bernadette Castro.   She approaches the task with such confidence in the product, such keen appreciation for its patented "feather lift" mechanism. "It goes up and over," she says, standing in the middle of the Castro Convertible showroom, tugging at the mechanism and effortlessly coaxing a bed frame and mattress out of a couch. "You just take it and pop it straight up."

nytimes_articles.headline: Paternity Suit Just Another Crisis in Rhode Island
nytimes_articles.abstract: Democrats and Republicans alike today dismissed an unfolding scandal over a paternity suit against Gov. Bruce Sundlun of Rhode Island as a titillating but temporary problem.   The suit was filed by a 17-year-old Michigan girl whose mother was involved with the 73-year old Democratic Governor for several years in the 1970's, after his second marriage.

nytimes_articles.headline: Judge in Boston Is Called Likely For High Court
nytimes_articles.abstract: After a week in which speculation swung from one candidate to another, White House officials said today that Stephen G. Breyer, a Federal appeals court judge from Boston, had emerged as President Clinton's most likely nominee for the Supreme Court.   Judge Breyer, who has been hospitalized since a bicycle accident last week, is scheduled to fly to Washington on Friday after his release to have lunch with Mr. Clinton. Several officials said the President hoped to make an announcement of a replacement for Justice Byron R. White, who is retiring, in the next two days.

nytimes_articles.headline: Rose Cancels Cooperstown Visit
nytimes_articles.abstract: PETE ROSE has canceled a trip to Cooperstown, N.Y., home of baseball's Hall of Fame, after he received criticism that the trip would steal the spotlight from REGGIE JACKSON, who is due to be inducted on Aug. 1.   Rose, baseball's career leader in hits, was banned from baseball for life in 1989 for having gambled on major league games and is ineligible for induction into the Hall of Fame.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Film; Waking Up To a Change: He Is a She
nytimes_articles.abstract: "Orlando" was shown as part of the New Directors/New Film Series. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 19, 1993. The film opens today at the Angelika Film Center, 18 West Houston Street, NoHo, and the Lincoln Plaza Cinemas, Broadway between 62d and 63d Streets, Manhattan.   Taking Virginia Woolf's bountiful and witty 1928 novel, "Orlando," which is as much about words, writing and the dogged pursuit of fine literature as about a number of other things, Sally Potter has made a grand new movie that is as much a richly informed appreciation of the novel as it is a free adaptation.

nytimes_articles.headline: MOYNIHAN HOLDING WELL-TIMED PARTY
nytimes_articles.abstract: A week before the Senate Finance Committee began reworking President Clinton's economic package, supporters of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan mailed invitations to lobbyists for a fund-raising event that reminded them of the New York Democrat's enhanced influence as chairman of the panel.   No laws were broken by Mr. Moynihan or by his campaign organization, and his aides noted that the Senator did not know who was invited nor who was responding to the invitation to an event that will be held a month after the committee completes its work.

nytimes_articles.headline:
Reformers, Martyrs and Chaperones;
One Big Union
nytimes_articles.abstract: In a contest sponsored by the New York Council for the Humanities, an affiliate of the National Endowment for the Humanities that seeks to bring scholarly thought to the general public, 275 of the state's high school students wrote 15-page historical research papers on "The Quest for Social Justice." The winners received college scholarships ranging from $500 to $5,000. The essays of several winners and finalists are adapted here.

nytimes_articles.headline: Morgan's Lawsuit Award Reduced
nytimes_articles.abstract: A Federal appeals court in San Francisco reversed a $450,000 punitive-damages award in a police-misconduct case involving Hall of Famer JOE MORGAN on the grounds that the award was too large. The appeals court upheld a lower court ruling that Morgan's constitutional rights were violated when he was detained by a police officer at Los Angeles International Airport in 1988. The court also upheld $90,000 in compensatory damages. (AP)

nytimes_articles.headline: Shares Hold Steady As Momentum Slows
nytimes_articles.abstract: TO see slowing momentum in action, or inaction, look at stock charts of money-center banks in the United States and Britain over the last year and a half. Many show substantial increases, often doubling or tripling in price. But over the last few months,

nytimes_articles.headline: A Fernandez Legacy to City Schools
nytimes_articles.abstract: When New York City Schools Chancellor Joseph Fernandez came to town three and a half years ago, he staked his reputation on giving teachers and parents more influence over what actually happens inside the schools. Now, as he prepares to leave, a Board of Education study shows that Mr. Fernandez was on the right track.    Many education reform efforts have been aimed at breaking the top-down model that imposes instructional guidelines and other rules devised by a distant bureaucracy. Mr. Fernandez has long been an important spokesman for a concept called school-based management.

nytimes_articles.headline: Lead Forces Closing of Parts of Two More Parks
nytimes_articles.abstract: After surveying nearly 70 sites under or near bridges, the New York City Parks Department said yesterday that it was closing sections of two more parks, including ballfields in the Bronx at the peak of the baseball season, because they were contaminated with debris containing potentially harmful levels of lead.   The public will be barred today from large sections of the parks -- Louis Cuvillier Park in Manhattan and Macombs Dam Park in the South Bronx -- so crews can remove contaminated paint chips, said Stewart Desmond, a spokesman for the Parks Department. The job could take weeks.

nytimes_articles.headline: School Board Seeks Refund Of Bus Fees
nytimes_articles.abstract: Last year, without warning, New York City school authorities alerted 37 bus companies about a costly mistake: Since 1986, the Board of Education said, it had overpaid the companies between $20 million and $22 million for student transportation and the board wanted its money back.   The bus companies, however, have refused to return a penny, contending that school administrators were responsible for the mix-up by switching in 1990 to a new system of computing contract increases and suddenly applying it retroactively.

nytimes_articles.headline: Classical Music in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Florilegium Chamber Choir The German Church 315 West 22d Street

nytimes_articles.headline: Observer; Terror In the Sunlight
nytimes_articles.abstract: While dozing in The Wall Street Journal the other day, I suddenly felt the hair rising on the back of my neck the way it does when I walk into the darkened parlor and see a long-dead relative poring over my Oxford English Dictionary's small-print edition with a magnifying glass.    The difference was that this sinister Wall Street Journal moment occurred while I was on the back porch in full afternoon sun whereas parlor sightings of long-dead relatives always occur late on misty evenings when the empty martini pitcher is still fresh with the smell of the juniper berry.

nytimes_articles.headline: Fees Dampen Boost in U.S. Fund Assets
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE 1,000-odd US mutual-fund executives who showed up for their annual get-together in Washington two weeks ago had plenty to celebrate. A record-breaking $21.6 billion flooded into stock and bond funds in April, fueled by investors' buying for their indi

nytimes_articles.headline: Nothing Elementary About the Elements
nytimes_articles.abstract: The United States Open seemed to have arrived a week early, in the second round of the Buick Classic, as swirling winds made for a survival test today rather than the kind of birdie assault customarily seen on the PGA Tour.   After 36 holes on a treacherous setup at the Westchester Country Club, only eight golfers were under par, with Tom Kite, Jeff Maggert and Duffy Waldorf tied for the lead at three-under-par 139.

nytimes_articles.headline: 1893: A Chastity Chest : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: PARIS - The railway pointsman named Lehuby, who adopted the careful practice of locking up his wife in a large trunk when he went out, has been sentenced by the Police Court of Louviers to pay a fine of 50fr. It appears that having some doubts about the f

nytimes_articles.headline: No Headline
nytimes_articles.abstract: "It's taken us so much pain to get here. All we heard was Americans really champion human rights. We were under the impression we would get to stay." -- CHEN FUXING, who described the immigrant voyage that ended on a Queens beach last week.  [ 24:6. ]

nytimes_articles.headline: Indians Complain of Religious and Cultural Theft
nytimes_articles.abstract: In a trendy art shop here, a fur-covered doll identified as a Navajo dancing bear glares from a shelf, its mouth agape and arms outstretched in a furious stance.   With a $170 price tag, the doll seems to be a cherished artifact of American Indian culture.

nytimes_articles.headline: Cheaper Student Loans in the Offing
nytimes_articles.abstract: Student loans will be cheaper, beginning with the 1994-95 academic year, if a bill approved Thursday by a Senate committee is enacted. The up-front fees charged to students would be cut in half to 4 percent of the loan amount from 8 percent now.   "It will be an immediate savings," said Madeleine Kunin, Deputy Secretary of Education. "And we're very confident it will be a more streamlined system."

nytimes_articles.headline: METRO DIGEST
nytimes_articles.abstract: A VOYAGE OF TERROR  As Chen Fuxing tells it, the Golden Venture's odyssey to America was a trial of desperation and fear. The lack of food, water, light and space broke the 300 travelers down and a kind of Darwinian order took shape. The weaker ones, who typically got the last scraps of a daily meal of rice and water, would beg for more. Page 1.  AT COLT, A SENSE OF BETRAYAL  Inside the rambling old red-brick fortress of Colt's Manufacturing Company in Hartford, where lines of the company's best-selling black military-style Sporter rifles stand ready for shipment, the sense of betrayal hangs as heavy as the aroma of machine oil. Page 1. NEW YORK CITY  NEW STRATEGY IN MOB CASE  In a new attempt to try Vincent Gigante on charges that he is the boss of a major crime family, Federal prosecutors say four defectors from the Mafia will testify that he is faking mental incompetency. Page 25.  DENTIST CHARGED WITH RAPE  A Bronx dentist has been arrested on charges that he twice raped a 16-year-old patient whom he had placed under anesthesia during a visit to his Melrose office, the police said. The girl, a patient of the dentist for several years, was hired for a summer job as his receptionist. Page 25.  A YOUNG TEACHER ALSO LEARNS  In Room 236 at Frederick Douglass Middle School in Harlem, Jennifer Hollis is a 20-year-old ingenue, a fresh-faced, open-hearted junior from Connecticut College who is there as an intern. Pupils in the school, just seven or eight years younger than her, stop at the door to look at her and point her out to each other. Page 25.  WHERE IS THE GRASS GREENER?  New Hampshire's state parks and recreation director was only trying to explain why he wanted to scrap some old playground equipment. The reason he gave: The state parks were starting to look like the Bronx. Apparently, he picked on the wrong borough. Page 25.  Operation Rescue's founder, Randall Terry, is sentenced to five months in jail. Page 10. REGION COOPERATION, NOT PROGRESS  In the best of circumstances, buying a cooperative requires as much coordination as juggling five balls in the air while riding a unicycle. Throw in the emotional politics and the personalities of the Yonkers desegregation case and things become even more difficult. Page 26.  6-YEAR TERM FOR FORMER TROOPER  Despite a plea for leniency and letters of support from 200 family members and friends, a judge in Ithaca, N.Y., sentenced a former state trooper to 6 to 18 years in prison for fabricating evidence in 21 criminal cases. Page 26.  CONTINUED FOSTER CARE FOR KATIE BEERS  Katie Beers, the 10-year-old who was kidnapped and held captive for 16 days in an underground prison, will remain in foster care for at least another year under an agreement reached in Suffolk County Family Court in Riverhead. Page 26.  FLORIO SIGNS ANTI-BIAS LAW  Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey has signed a bill to allow victims of bias crimes to sue their assailants. Page 8.

nytimes_articles.headline: Energy Tax Quest: Levy That Draws Least Outcry
nytimes_articles.abstract: As it seeks to find a replacement for the Administration's B.T.U. tax, the Senate is struggling to choose the least ugly of several alternatives.   It has quickly discovered that every option has somebody ready to loathe it.

nytimes_articles.headline: BRIEFCASE : Japanese Investors Turn To Foreign Bond Purchases
nytimes_articles.abstract: One noted aspect of U.S. investing patterns, an increasing tendency to buy securities outside the United States, is being followed, at least in part, by Japanese investors, who bought a net $6.83 billion in non-Japanese bonds in April, according to figur

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
